It contested by Real Zaragoza, who were Spanish Cup winners in 2003–04, and Valencia CF, who won the [[La Liga 2003–04|2003–04]] Spanish League. Real Zaragoza won 3–2 on aggregate. ==Match details== ===First leg=== {{footballbox |date = 21 August 2004 |time = 22:00 [[Central European Time|CET]] |team1 = [[Real Zaragoza|Zaragoza]] |score = 0–1 {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=January 2008}} {{original research|date=January 2008}} }} {{expand list|date=October 2015}} '''[[List of association football clubs|Association Football club]] names''' are a part of the [[association football|sport]]'s culture, reflecting century-old traditions. Club names may reflect the geographical, cultural, religious or political affiliations – or simply be the brand name of a club's primary sponsor. Because of the British [[History of association football|origin of the modern game]] and the prevalence of the English language, many clubs, even outside Europe, have their names written in English. Official names often also contain common component (prepositions, conjunctions, etc.) In Europe, many (if not most) clubs are named after their towns or cities (e.g. "[[Deportivo La Coruña]]", "[[Liverpool F.C.]]", "[[Hamburger SV]]"). In South America, clubs are more likely to have names that don't bear the city's name. Some clubs, like [[Hansa Rostock]] or [[Torpedo Moscow]] may have both. ==Common versus official usage== {{See also|Lists of nicknames in association football}} It is not uncommon for a club to be known in common usage by a name other than its official name, or the name on the badge. Other clubs are more usually known by [[nicknames]] or contractions of their full names, for instance, [[Clube de Regatas Vasco da Gama|Vasco da Gama]] is usually called simply "Vasco", [[F.C. Internazionale Milano]] is contracted to ''Inter'' or ''Inter Milan'', [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]] is often called ''Sporting'' or ''Sporting Lisbon''. [[Manchester United]] is often shortened to ''Man Utd'', and ''Lyon'' used instead of [[Olympique Lyonnais]]. Some clubs are commonly referred to by their initials, such as PSG for [[Paris Saint-Germain]] and PNE for Preston North End. ==Profession/education== ===Profession=== {|class="wikitable" align="center" !width="150"|Topic !width="200"|Meaning !width="100"|Country !width="250"|Clubs |- | rowspan="10" valign="middle" |'''Armed forces''' | rowspan="10" valign="middle" |For sport clubs affiliated with the armed forces of a country. revision.text:
{{Infobox football club | clubname = Ferroviarios | image = ferroviarios de chile.png | fullname = Club Deportivo Ferroviarios de Chile | nickname = ''Ferro'' (Rail), ''Locomotora'' (Locomotive) | founded = July 14, 1916 | ground = Estadio Los Nogales,
[[Estacion Central]], [[Santiago]] | capacity = 220 | chairman = Luis Tapia | manager = Máximo Romero | league = [[Tercera B (Chile)|Tercera B]] | season = 2017 | position = 6th (Center zone) | pattern_la1 = _black_stripes|pattern_b1=_blackstripes|pattern_ra1=_black_stripes | leftarm1 = FFF000|body1=FFF000|rightarm1=FFF000|shorts1=000000|socks1=FFF000 | pattern_la2 = |pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2 = FFFFFF|body2=FF0000|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=000000|socks2=000000 }} '''Club Deportivo Ferroviarios de Chile''' is a [[Chile]]an [[Football club]] based in [[Estacion Central|Estacion Central, Santiago]]. They currently play at the fifth level of Chilean football, the [[Tercera B (Chile)|Tercera B]]. The club was founded on July 14, 1916 by [[railroad]] workers in the Barrio San Eugenio; and on February 23, 1950 when they merged with [[Santiago Badminton]], until 1969 they were known as ''Ferrobadminton''. Badminton then decided to undo the merger and moved to [[Curicó]]. In 1980, the club moved to [[Talagante]] and adopted the name of ''Talagante-Ferro''. In 1982 was renamed as Ferroviarios. ==Honours== * '''División de Honor Amateur (DIVHA)''': '''3''' ** 1947, 1948, 1949 * '''[[Chilean Cuarta División|Cuarta División]]''': '''1''' ** 2003 ---- *'''1''' ''season'' in ''[[Chilean Primera División|Primera División]]'' *'''14''' ''seasons'' in ''[[Chilean Primera División B|Primera B]]'' *'''12''' ''seasons'' in ''[[Chilean Tercera División|Tercera División]]'' *'''17''' ''seasons'' in ''[[Chilean Cuarta División|Cuarta División]]'' ==Records== *'''Record [[Primera División de Chile|Primera División]] victory''' — 7–1 ''v.'' [[Santiago Morning|Morning Star]] (1934) *'''Record [[Primera División de Chile|Primera División]] defeat''' — 0–6 ''v.'' [[Colo-Colo]] (1934) *'''[[Primera División de Chile|Primera División]] Best Position''' — 9th (1934) ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071011004325/http://ferrofutbol.cl/ Official website] {{es icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ferroviarios}} [[Category:1916 establishments in Chile]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1916]] [[Category:Football clubs in Chile]] {{Chile-sport-stub}} {{SouthAm-footyclub-stub}}

Many sports leagues, sportswriting associations, and other organizations confer "'''Coach of the Year'''" awards. In some sports — including baseball and association football — the award is called the "Manager of the Year" award.
Some of these are: * [[AFCA Coach of the Year]] (American collegiate football) (US) * [[Annis Stukus Trophy]] (Canadian Football League) * [[Clair Bee Coach of the Year Award|Clair Bee Coach of the Year]] (NCAA Division I basketball) (US) * [[Henry Iba Award]] (NCAA basketball) (US) * IHJUK [[Coach of the Year Trophy (IHJUK)|Coach of the Year Trophy]] (Ice Hockey Journalists UK) * [[Jack Adams Award]] (National Hockey League) (Canada & US) * [[Major Indoor Soccer League (2001–2008)#Coach of the Year Award|Major Indoor Soccer League (US) Coach of the Year]] * [[Major League Lacrosse Coach of the Year Award|Major League Lacrosse (US) Coach of the Year]] * [[MLS Coach of the Year Award|Major League Soccer (US) Coach of the Year]] * [[Naismith College Coach of the Year]] (NCAA Division I basketball) (US) * [[NBA Coach of the Year Award|National Basketball Association (US) Coach of the Year]] * [[NBL (Australia) Coach of the Year|National Basketball League (Australia) Coach of the Year]] * [[NFL Coach of the Year Award|National Football League (US) Coach of the Year]] * [[Coach of the Year (ice hockey)|Swedish Ice Hockey Coach of the Year]] * [[USOC Coach of the Year|United States Olympic Committee Coach of the Year]] * [[WNBA Coach of the Year Award|Women's National Basketball Association (US) Coach of the Year]] * [[Golden Goggle Awards#Coach of the Year|USA Swimming Golden Goggle Awards Coach of the Year]]
==See also== *[[Coach Award]] (BBC Sports Personality of the Year) (UK) *[[Best Coach/Manager ESPY Award]] (all sports) (US) *[[Manager of the Year Award]] (Major League Baseball) (US) *[[German Football Manager of the Year]] *[[Philips Sports Manager of the Year]] (Ireland) *[[Premier League Manager of the Season]] (England)
[[Category:Coaching awards| ]]

[[File:Nano Action.JPG|thumb|[[Camille Leblanc-Bazinet]], 2014 Reebok CrossFit Games Champion, during the Thick 'n Quick event of the 2014 CrossFit Games ]]
The '''CrossFit Games''' is an athletic competition sponsored by [[CrossFit|Crossfit Inc.]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidtao/2013/06/02/how-crossfit-embraced-fans-and-became-the-next-great-spectator-sport/ |title=How CrossFit Embraced Fans and became the next great spectator sport| publisher=Forbes.com |date=June 2, 2013 |accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref> and [[Reebok]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.marketingweek.com/2015/07/22/reebok-in-relaunch-phase-as-it-looks-to-become-top-fitness-brand/|title=Reebok in ‘relaunch phase’ as it looks to become top fitness brand|last=Millington|first=Alison|website=Marketing Week|access-date=2016-04-06}}</ref> The competition has been held every summer since 2007. Athletes at the Games compete in workouts that they learn about hours or days beforehand, consisting mostly of an assortment of standard aerobic, weightlifting, and gymnastics movements, as well as some additional surprise elements that are not part of the typical CrossFit regimen such as [[obstacle course]]s, ocean swimming, softball throwing, or ascending a pegboard.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://games.crossfit.com/article/major-announcement-individuals|title=Major Announcement for Individuals|website=CrossFit Games|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mensfitness.com/training/pro-tips/why-pegboard-challenge-crossfit-games-was-such-beast|title=Why the Pegboard Challenge at the CrossFit Games Was Such a Beast|website=Men's Fitness|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref> The CrossFit Games stylizes their individual winners as the "Fittest on Earth".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/crossfit-and-btwb-unite-to-help-athletes-and-affiliates-improve-health-300670112.html |title=CrossFit And BTWB Unite To Help Athletes And Affiliates Improve Health |work=[[PR Newswire]] |date=June 21, 2018}}</ref>
==History== In 2007, the first annual CrossFit Games were contested in [[Aromas, California]], on a small ranch owned by the family of Games director Dave Castro.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://journal.crossfit.com/2010/07/games-history.tpl|title=The History of the CrossFit Games by Dave Castro|website=CrossFit Journal|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref> For the initial Games in 2007 and 2008, participation was open to anyone who made it to Aromas. The Games would also award an Affiliate Cup to the group from one CrossFit gym that had the best combined individual standings. In 2009, competitors had to qualify after over a hundred athletes had shown up in 2008. The athletes earned an invitation through either placing high enough in the previous year or through placing in the top worldwide in a set of qualifying events called Regionals hosted at a few CrossFit gyms. The CrossFit Games also added a separate set of team-based events for the Affiliate Cup, marking the first use of a designated Team Division, with teams of four (two men and two women).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://games2009.crossfit.com/starthere.html |title=Start Here: An Introduction to the CrossFit Games |publisher=2009 CrossFit Games |access-date=November 30, 2017}}</ref>
Interest and participation in the event continued to grow, and in 2010, the qualification was adjusted to include hosting multiple Sectionals, a series of events open to all athletes in order to qualify for the one of the 17 Regionals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://games.crossfit.com/region|title=Regionals|website=CrossFit Games|access-date=2016-05-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504044746/http://games.crossfit.com/region|archive-date=2016-05-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The 17 regions had Canada and the United States divided into 12 regions, with the remaining regions roughly corresponding the five other populated continents. The attendance at the Games also outgrew the ranch in Aromas and moved the [[Home Depot Center]] (later called the StubHub Center) in [[Carson, California]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://games.crossfit.com/article/games-tickets-2015|title=Games Tickets in 2015|website=CrossFit Games|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref> The Games also expanded the Team Division to groups of six athletes and added a Masters Division for individual men and women 55-years-old and up.
In 2011, the open participation Sectionals were replaced by an online qualification called the Open. In 2011, 26,000 athletes signed up to compete in the Open. In 2012–2018, participation was 69,000, 138,000, 209,000, 273,000, 324,307, 380,000, and 415,000 respectively.<ref>{{Citation|last=CrossFit®|title=Stats From the 2016 Open|date=2016-04-11|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e9W-0bpqG_s|accessdate=2016-05-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tabatatimes.com/how-fast-are-the-crossfit-games-growing-the-numbers-tell-the-story/ |title=How Fast Are the CrossFit Games Growing? The Numbers Tell the Story |publisher=Tabata Times |accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://games.crossfit.com/article/209585-rise-open |title=209,585: Rise of the Open |publisher=CrossFit Games |date=March 26, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://games.crossfit.com/article/inside-leaderboard-scale-or-not-scale |title=INSIDE THE LEADERBOARD: TO SCALE, OR NOT TO SCALE |publisher=CrossFit Games |date=April 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://games.crossfit.com/video/2017-open-recap |title=2017 OPEN RECAP |publisher=CrossFit Games |date=March 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://games.crossfit.com/article/open-success-stories/open|title=Open Success Stories|work=CrossFit Games|access-date=2018-05-30}}</ref>
In 2015, the qualification format changed from 17 regional events to eight. Each "super-regional" event included qualifiers from two or three of the previously defined regions, totaling 40 or 50 athletes at each event.
Following seven years in Carson, the Games moved to the [[Alliant Energy Center]] in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/crossfit-games-moving-to-madison/article_771c7470-6841-5d7a-b65f-d9a93eab1691.html |title=CrossFit Games moving to Madison |publisher=''[[Wisconsin State Journal]]'' |date=November 21, 2016}}</ref> The next year, the qualifying Regionals were once again realigned due to increased competitiveness and popularity outside of Canada and the US.<ref name = "2018Changes">{{cite web |url=https://games.crossfit.com/article/change-coming-2018-season/liftoff |title=CHANGE IS COMING TO THE 2018 SEASON |publisher=CrossFit Games |date=November 30, 2017}}</ref> In 2018, there were nine Regionals hosted among 18 redefined regions with Europe increasing to three regions, Central America split from South America, while eliminating the Northern and Southern California regions.
CrossFit, Inc. founder Greg Glassman has stated that the format for the 2019 games will be changed again with the replacement of the typical Regionals for CrossFit-sanctioned international qualifying events.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://morningchalkup.com/2018/08/23/how-greg-glassman-is-reshaping-the-crossfit-games/ |title=How Greg Glassman is Reshaping the CrossFit Games |website=MorningChalkUp.com |date=August 23, 2018}}</ref> As part of the changes, the 2019 games athletes qualify through being the top individual and team finishers from the sanctioned events, the top athlete from each country in the CrossFit Open, the top 20 overall finishers in the CrossFit Open, and four at-large athletes as chosen by CrossFit, Inc. Teams also no longer need to be created from one CrossFit-affiliated gym and can be formed from any four competitors.<ref name="4more">{{cite web |url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/crossfit-announces-four-more-sanctioned-events-on-four-continents-300717444.html |title=CrossFit Announces Four More Sanctioned Events on Four Continents |website=prnewswire.com |date=September 24, 2018}}</ref>
===Sponsorship and prize money=== Participation and sponsorship have grown rapidly since the inception of the Games. The prize money awarded to each first-place male and female increased from $500 at the inaugural Games to $275,000 from 2013 to 2016. The largest jump in prize money came from the first Games sponsored by [[Reebok]] in 2011 when first place went from $25,000 in 2010 to $250,000 in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/sportsmoney/2011/07/22/crossfits-relationship-with-reebok-enhances-its-financial-and-commercial-credibility/#5d0d02653ab2 |title=CrossFit's Relationship with Reebok Enhances Its Financial and Commercial Credibility |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=July 22, 2011}}</ref> The total prize payout in 2016 was $2,200,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://games.crossfit.com/article/crossfit-games-prize-purse-grows |title=CrossFit Games Prize Purse Grows |publisher=CrossFit Games |date=July 7, 2014}}</ref>
==Stages of qualification (2019)== As of the 2019 CrossFit Games, the season consisted of three stages of competition: the Open, sanctioned events, and the Games themselves. This format was changed for the 2019 season, in which the CrossFit, Inc. hosted Regionals were replaced by independently run CrossFit-sanctioned events.
===The Open=== The Open, introduced in [[2011 CrossFit Games|2011]] and so called because participation is open to anyone,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://games.crossfit.com/about-the-games|title=About the Games|website=CrossFit Games|access-date=2016-04-06}}</ref> is held over five weeks in February–March; a new workout is released on each Thursday night ([[Pacific Time Zone|Pacific Time]]) and competitors complete the workout and submit their scores online by Monday evening, with either a video or validation by a CrossFit affiliate. Since 2013, Open workout announcements have been broadcast live, and featured two or more past CrossFit Games athletes competing head-to-head immediately following the workout description. Beginning with the 2019 Games, the top athlete from each country and the top 20 overall Open finishers qualify directly to the Games.
===Sanctioned events=== Between 2009 and 2018, competitors would qualify for the Games through participation an the Regionals. For the 2019 Games, CrossFit, Inc. decided to discontinue hosting the Regional qualifier and instead sanctioned previous independent fitness events as qualifiers separate from the Open. These sanctioned events were already widely participated in by CrossFit Games athletes, often used as a part of off-season training, around the world.
As of November 1, 2018, the sanctioned events for the [[2019 CrossFit Games]] are in chronological order: Dubai CrossFit Championship ([[Dubai]]), Wodapalooza ([[Miami]]), Australian CrossFit Championship ([[Broadbeach]]), CrossFit Fittest in [[Cape Town]], CrossFit Strength in Depth ([[London]]), CrossFit French Throwdown ([[Paris]]), Asia CrossFit Championship ([[Shanghai]]), Mid-Atlantic CrossFit Challenge ([[Baltimore]]), CrossFit Italian Showdown ([[Milan]]), Brazil CrossFit Championship ([[São Paulo]]), CrossFit Lowlands Throwdown ([[Apeldoorn]]), Down Under CrossFit Championship ([[Wollongong]]), Reykjavik CrossFit Championship ([[Reykjavik]]), [[Rogue Fitness|Rogue]] Invitational ([[Columbus, Ohio]]), and the Granite Games ([[St. Cloud, Minnesota]]).<ref name="4more"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/crossfit-inc-officially-sanctions-global-fitness-festival-wodapalooza-300722068.html |title=CrossFit, Inc. Officially Sanctions Global Fitness Festival Wodapalooza |website=PRNewswire.com |date=October 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://morningchalkup.com/2018/10/10/crossfit-firms-up-games-changes-announces-four-sanctioned-events/ |title=CrossFit Firms Up Games Changes, Announces Four New Sanctioned Events |website=MorningChalkUp.com |date=October 10, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/five-new-crossfit-sanctioned-competitive-events-announced-300739201.html |title=Five New CrossFit-Sanctioned Competitive Events Announced |website=PRNewswire.com |date=October 29, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://barbend.com/2019-crossfit-games-rogue-invitational/ |title=16th Sanctioned Event Announced for the 2019 CrossFit Games |website=BarBend.com |date=November 1, 2018}}</ref>
===Games=== The top athletes from each sanctioned event, each national champion in the Open, the top twenty overall finishers in the Open, and four at-large invitees advance to the CrossFit Games, which are held over three days in July or August.
==Divisions== ===Individual=== The marquee events at the CrossFit Games are the men's and women's individual competitions. The first place prize for each currently stands at $300,000.
===Team=== Originally, teams were awarded the "Affiliate Cup" for having the best overall score from the individual athletes that had come from the same CrossFit-affiliated gym. In 2009, the Games began having a separate set of events for affiliate teams and consisted of four to six athletes from the same gym.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://games2009.crossfit.com/affiliatecup/the-crossfit-games-2009-affiliate-cup-challenge.html |title=Affiliate Cup Registration Opens Monday, May 11th |website=games2009.crossfit.com |date=May 10, 2009}}</ref> The next season, the format was finalized to teams of three men and three women. In the 2018 games, each team was changed to four members, two men and two women.<ref name = "2018Changes"/> In 2019, CrossFit removed the stipulation that team members had to be from the same affiliate. Teams are subject to a similar qualification process as the individuals.
===Masters and Teens=== The Games include age-based divisions for younger and older competitors. Masters divisions were introduced at the 2010 Games. There are currently six divisions each for women and men: 35–39, 40–44, 45–49, 50–54, 55–59, and 60+. Divisions for teenagers were introduced in 2015: the age ranges are 14–15 and 16–17, for both boys and girls. Rather than regional events, masters and teen athletes qualify for the games by a second online competition following the Open. The top 200 athletes in each division worldwide are invited to compete in this qualifier, of which the top 20 advance to the Games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://games.crossfit.com/article/2017-reebok-crossfit-games-season-schedule |title=2017 REEBOK CROSSFIT GAMES SEASON SCHEDULE |publisher=CrossFit Games |date=November 15, 2016}}</ref> Prior to the introduction of these secondary online qualifiers, masters and teens competitors qualified for the Games directly from the Open.
==Controversies== Due to CrossFit's official partnership with [[Reebok]], competitors at the [[2015 CrossFit Games|2015 Games]] were banned from wearing [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] footwear.<ref name="nikeban">{{cite web|title=CrossFit bans Nike shoe|url=http://www.mensfitness.com/life/gearandtech/crossfit-bans-nike-shoe|author=Lydia Bailey|publisher=[[Men's Fitness]]|date=July 13, 2015}}</ref> Nike arranged for several trucks to be parked near the main entrance to the arena, which served as [[mobile billboards]] with the slogan "Don't ban our shoe, beat our shoe".<ref>{{cite web|title=Nike Isn't Done Bullying Reebok Over CrossFit|url=http://solecollector.com/news/2015/07/nike-reebok-crossfit-games|author=Brendan Dunne|publisher=[[Sole collector|Sole Collector]]|date=July 28, 2015}}</ref> The partnership also prohibits Nike from labeling its ''Metcon'' shoes as intended for CrossFit – the brand uses the term "high intensity training" instead.<ref name="nikeban" />
CrossFit's decision to award winners of the [[2016 CrossFit Games|2016 Games]] with [[handguns]] resulted in widespread criticism from members and sponsors.<ref>{{cite web|title=CrossFit Games come under fire for awarding Glocks as prizes|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-crossfit-games-glock-prizes-20160715-snap-htmlstory.html|author=Joseph Serna|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 15, 2016}}</ref> Resulting protests forced the temporary closure of two CrossFit locations in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anti-Gun LGBT Group Shuts Down Two CrossFit Locations Over Gun Giveaway|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/gays-against-guns-crossfit-reeboks_us_5796448ce4b02d5d5ed24e7e|author=JamesMichael Nichols|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|date=July 25, 2016}}</ref>
== Broadcasting == In 2011, [[ESPN]] began to broadcast the CrossFit Games, with live coverage streamed through [[ESPN3]], and some television coverage on [[ESPN2]]. As the event grew, ESPN expanded its television coverage; in 2014, the network entered into a multi-year deal to continue broadcasting the CrossFit Games, and coverage expanded to nine-and-a-half hours on ESPN and ESPN2 by 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://boxlifemagazine.com/espn-the-crossfit-games-how-it-all-started-what-it-means-now-the-2015-tv-schedule/|title=ESPN & the CrossFit Games: How It All Started & What It Means Now (+ the 2015 TV Schedule)|work=BoxLife Magazine|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-us}}</ref> In 2017, the event began a new broadcast arrangement with [[CBS Sports]], with television coverage on [[CBS Sports Network]], and a total of 40 hours of digital streaming coverage. CrossFit also streamed coverage through [[Facebook]] and their website.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sportsvideo.org/2017/08/04/crossfit-games-expand-pursuit-for-fittest-on-earth-with-new-network-partner-new-venue/|title=CrossFit Games Expand Pursuit of ‘Fittest on Earth’ With New Network Partner, New Venue|website=Sports Video Group|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
==Champions by year and category==
'''Individual and Team champions'''<ref name = "CFLeaderboard">{{cite web |url=http://games.crossfit.com/leaderboard |title=CrossFit Games Leaderboard |accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Year !! Individual Men !! Individual Women !! {{Infobox football club | nickname = ''Albicelestes'', ''Carabeleros'',
''Manojito de Claveles'', ''Academia'', ''El Viejo y Querido'' | ground = [[:es:Estadio Municipal de San Bernardo|Estadio Municipal de San Bernardo]],
[[San Bernardo, Chile|San Bernardo, Santiago]] | capacity = 3,500 | season = 2018 | pattern_la1=_whiteborder | pattern_la2=_whiteborder | pattern_b2 = _magallanes11a | pattern_ra1 = _whiteborder | pattern_ra2 = _whiteborder | pattern_sh1 = | leftarm1=0099FF | leftarm2=FF0000 | body1 = FFFFFF | body2 = FF0000 | rightarm1 = 0099FF | rightarm2 = FF0000 | shorts1 = 000000 | shorts2 = 000000 | socks1 = FFFFFF | socks2 = 000000 | clubname = Magallanes | image = CDMagallanes.png | fullname = Club Deportivo Magallanes | founded = October 27, 1897 | chairman = Anselmo Palma | manager = [[Óscar Correa]] | league = [[Chilean Primera División B|Primera B]] | position = 13th | pattern_b1 = _magallanes11h | }}{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} '''Deportes Magallanes'''{{Cite web|url=http://www.svs.cl/institucional/mercados/entidad.php?auth=&send=&mercado=O&rut=96913170&grupo=&tipoentidad=OTODP&vig=VI&row=AABcNzAB9AAAD62AAA&control=svs&pestania=1|title=DEPORTES MAGALLANES S.A.D.P. – Identificacion – SVS|website=www.svs.cl|access-date=2017-03-07}} are a Chilean [[Football club|Football team]] based in San Bernardo, Chile. They currently play at the second level of Chilean football, the Primera B de Chile. The club was founded on October 27, 1897 with the name Atlético Escuela Normal F.C.. In 1933 they became the first ever national champions of Chile. They won a hat trick of titles in the formative years of Chilean football (1933, 1934 and 1935) but their last major title came in 1938. Their latest participation in the first level was in 1986. Deportes Magallanes, adopting their official name in 1904, is one of the oldest clubs in the country. Since the year 2000, after accepting the establishment of Policy number 20.019, the team has been managed by a [[Sociedad Anónima Deportiva|limited sports company]].{{Cite web|url=http://lmtavocats.de/fr/images_db/report_france_ba_2013__sport_ws_final.pdf|title=Football. Funding and Restructuring in Today's Markets.|last=Héry|first=Christophe|date=March 5, 2013|website=lmtavocats.de|archive-url=http://lmtavocats.de/fr/images_db/report_france_ba_2013__sport_ws_final.pdf|archive-date=March 5, 2013|dead-url=|access-date=March 6, 2017}} It is one of the eight founding clubs of the [[Asociación Nacional de Fútbol Profesional|Nation Chilean Football League]], the first football league established in the country, which also instituted the [[Chilean Primera División|Premier Division]] (Primera Division) of Chile. In this league, Magallanes won their first championship in 1933. In addition, they were the first club to win three consecutive professional championships in Chile. The club adopted white and [[sky blue]] as their official colors in 1908. These colors are used in their sportswear as well as their [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|logo]], which depicts a [[Ship|Caravel]] on the ocean. Since August 2015, Magallanes has practiced in their hometown of San Bernardohttp://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/detail/detail?sid=7b1da573-f07d-4852-b19d-d520e4443178@sessionmgr120&vid=0&hid=111&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWRzLWxpdmUmc2NvcGU9c2l0ZQ==#AN=clelmercuriotxt267588&db=pwh{{full citation needed|date=March 2017}} in the city stadium, which seats 3,500 spectators. They often compete in the Metropolitan Classic against their longtime rival, [[Santiago Morning]]. In addition, they compete in a championship called de la Chilenidad, where they face off against another rival team, [[Colo-Colo]]. Magallanes is ranked sixth for national titles in the Premier Division, tying [[Everton de Viña del Mar]] and [[Audax Italiano]], with four each.{{Cite web|url=http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chilechamp.html|title=Chile – List of Champions and Runners-up|website=rsssf.com|access-date=2017-03-07}} They have been the runner up behind Colo-Colo, [[Club Universidad de Chile|Universidad de Chile]], [[Club Deportivo Universidad Católica|Universidad Católica]], [[C.D. Cobreloa|Cobreloa]] and [[Unión Española]]. They also have one title from the [[Chilean Tercera División|Third Division]] (Tercera Division),{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/teams/chile/club-deportivo-magallanes/11184/trophies/|title=Chile – Club Deportivo Magallanes – Results, fixtures, squad, statistics, photos, videos and news – Soccerway|website=us.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-07}} one title from the [[Campeonato de Apertura (Chile)|Campeonato de Apertura]],{{Cite journal|date=September 1, 2016|title=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|url=https://es.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Rec.Sport.Soccer_Statistics_Foundation&oldid=93335498|journal=Wikipedia, la enciclopedia libre|language=es}} one from the Campeonato Relámpago and one from the Campeonato Absoluto. Despite their lack of titles in the last 70 years the club are still ranked as the seventh most successful team in the history of Chilean football. ==Titles== *'''[[Primera División de Chile|Primera División]]: 4''' ::1933, 1934, 1935, 1938 *'''[[Campeonato de Apertura (Chile)|Campeonato de Apertura (Cup)]]: 1''' ::1937 *'''[[Tercera División A de Chile|Tercera División A]]: 2''' ::1995, 2010 ==Performance in CONMEBOL competitions== *'''[[Copa Libertadores]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[1985 Copa Libertadores|1985]]: First Round ==Current squad== {{Magallanes squad|format=table}} ===2018 Winter Transfers=== ====In==== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no= 2|nat=BRA|pos=DF|name=[[Antônio Carlos (footballer)|Antonio Carlos]]|other=from [[Brusque Futebol Clube|Brusque]]}} {{Fs player|no=13|nat=URU|pos=FW|name=[[Sebastián Abreu]]|other=from [[Audax Italiano]]}} {{Fs mid}} {{Fs player|no=31|nat=CHI|pos=DF|name=[[Francisco Ugarte (footballer, born 1986)|Francisco Ugarte]]|other=from [[Tulsa Roughnecks]]}} {{Fs end}} ====Out==== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no= 2|nat=URU|pos=DF|name=[[Rodrigo Brasesco]]|other=to [[Racing de Montevideo]]}} {{Fs player|no= 7|nat=CHI|pos=FW|name=[[Mauro Lopes]]|other=loaned to [[Deportes Santa Cruz]]}} {{Fs player|no=15|nat=CHI|pos=MF|name=[[Luis Torres Varas|Luis Torres]]|other=loaned to [[Deportes Santa Cruz]]}} {{Fs mid}} {{Fs player|no=18|nat=CHI|pos=MF|name=[[Nicolás Pérez]]|other=loaned to [[Deportes Santa Cruz]]}} {{Fs player|no=28|nat=ARG|pos=MF|name=[[Miguel Escobar]]|other=to [[Asociación Social y Deportiva Justo José de Urquiza|JJ Urquiza]]}} {{Fs player|no=--|nat=CHI|pos=MF|name=[[Benjamín Carrasco Ortiz|Benjamín Carrasco]]|other=loaned to [[Deportes Santa Cruz]]}} {{Fs end}} ==Managers== *{{flagicon|Chile}} [[Luis Tirado]] (1931) *{{flagicon|Hungary|1940}} [[Máximo Garay]] (1942) *{{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Ricardo Dabrowski]] (1993) *{{flagicon|Chile}} [[Francisco Valdés]] (1997) *{{flagicon|Chile}} [[Osvaldo Heriberto Hurtado Galeguillo|Osvaldo Hurtado]] (2008–??) *{{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Pablo Abraham]] (2015–) ==See also== *[[Chilean football league system]] ==References== Magallanes Supporter´s site] {{es icon}} {{Liga Chilena de Fútbol: Primera B}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Magallanes}} [[Category:Football clubs in Chile]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in {{Infobox venue | name = Diamond Nation | nickname = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = Diamond Nation logo.png | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = New Jersey | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = Location in New Jersey | pushpin_label_position = | address = 129 River Road, [[Flemington, New Jersey|Flemington]], [[New Jersey]] | location = | coordinates = {{coord|40|32|8|N|74|50|48|W|type:landmark_region:US-NJ|display=inline,title}} | type = Baseball complex | genre = [[Sporting events]] | broke_ground = | built = | opened = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[Artificial turf]] | scoreboard = Yes | production = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = New Jersey Diamond Jacks (2000-''present'') | embedded = | website = {{URL|diamondnation.com}} | publictransit = }} '''Diamond Nation''' is a 65-acre baseball complex in [[Flemington, New Jersey|Flemington]], [[New Jersey]] that was established in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Facility Overview|url=http://www.diamondnation.com/facility-overview.html|publisher=Diamond Nation|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref> It is home to Jack Cust Baseball Academy and Jennie Finch Softball Academy making itself a premier baseball and softball tournament and training center in the country. Diamond Nation currently has seven fields in total. Five of them are with ninety foot base paths, which can be converted into two little league fields each. The other two are seventy foot base paths.
The New Jersey Diamond Jacks, which is run by Jack Cust Baseball Academy, was established as an elite 18U organization. The association has expanded to include teams from the 10U age to 18U.<ref>{{cite web|title=Diamond Jacks|url=http://www.diamondnation.com/diamond-jacks.html|publisher=Diamond Nation|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref>
Multiple New Jersey high school baseball teams play games at Diamond Nation throughout the spring season.<ref>{{cite web|author1=James Kratch|title=Baseball: 8 Opening Day games to watch on Wednesday, April 1|url=http://highschoolsports.nj.com/news/article/-5151003507610760695/baseball-opening-day-games-to-watch-on-wednesday-april-1/|publisher=NJ.com|accessdate=1 April 2015|date=1 April 2015|quote=The game will be played at Diamond Nation in Flemington, so there should be no issues with getting this one in.}}</ref>
On 20 July 2012, Diamond Nation released '''Club Diamond Nation''' which is a virtual baseball and softball training academy.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Cristina Rojas/Hunterdon County Democrat|title=Diamond Nation launching virtual baseball and softball academy July 20|url=http://www.nj.com/hunterdon-county-democrat/index.ssf/2012/07/diamond_nation_launching_virtu.html|publisher=NJ.com|accessdate=1 April 2015|date=18 July 2012}}</ref>
In early 2014, Diamond Nation made proposals to build another complex in [[Fredericksburg, Virginia|Fredericksburg]], [[Virginia]] that would be home to [[Minor League Baseball]] team, [[Hagerstown Suns]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Benjamin Hill|title=Batting Around: A Minor League Baseball business roundup|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20140116&content_id=66676330&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_milb|publisher=[[Minor League Baseball]]|accessdate=1 April 2015|date=16 January 2014|quote=A 4,750-seat baseball stadium for the relocated minor league team and five artificial turf fields for Diamond Nation youth and amateur baseball and softball camps and tournaments will be built there.}}</ref>
== Facility == Located at Diamond Nation are the '''HealthQuest Fitness Club''', and the '''HealthQuest Sports Dome'''. The Fitness Club was founded in 2001 and, open year round, is one of the top fitness clubs in the entire world with 104,000 square feet. The 140,000 square foot Sports Dome was built in 2003 and is the largest air structure in the [[United States]]. The Sports Dome temporarily covers HealthQuest Park from November to March to allow elite competition and training to continue to progress through the winter months.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Hunterdon County Democrat|title=Inflatable dome rises over Raritan Township baseball academy for the 11th year|url=http://www.nj.com/hunterdon-county-democrat/index.ssf/2012/11/inflatable_dome_rises_over_rar.html|publisher=NJ.com|accessdate=1 April 2015|date=17 November 2012}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Baseball venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports in Hunterdon County, New Jersey]] [[Category:High school baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:2009 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:Softball venues in the United States]]

'''Disqualifications in tennis''' can occur for unsporting conduct. ATP rules state that:
Players shall not at any time physically abuse any official, opponent, spectator or other person within the precincts of the tournament site. For purposes of this rule, physical abuse is the unauthorized touching of an official, opponent, and spectator or other person.{{cn|date=May 2013}}
==Disqualified players== Disqualifications in tennis are relatively rare: *In 1990 [[John McEnroe]] was disqualified in his fourth-round match against [[Mikael Pernfors]] at the [[Australian Open]] for three code violations.{{cite web|title=John McEnroe disqualified from the Australian Open|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/john-mcenroe-disqualified-from-the-australian-open|publisher=History.com|accessdate=27 September 2012}} *In 1995 [[Tim Henman]] was disqualified for hitting a ball girl with a shot.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/tennis/18477343|title=Wimbledon archive: Henman disqualified for hitting ball girl|accessdate=2013-05-30|date=17 June 2012|publisher=[[BBC]]}} *In 1996 [[Irina Spîrlea]] was disqualified for abusive language directed at an official.[http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/246797/Nova-and-out-for-shamed-Ana.html?print=yes Nova and out for shamed Ana] *In 2007 [[Anastasia Rodionova]] was disqualified for hitting a ball at spectators cheering her opponent [[Angelique Kerber]]. Kerber was awarded the match 4–6, 6–4, 1–0.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/6903967.stm BBC SPORT | Tennis | Russian disqualified in WTA event] *In 2012 [[David Nalbandian]] was disqualified for injuring an official after kicking an advertising board.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2160617/Argentine-tennis-player-David-Nalbandian-booted-Queens-Club-final-wild-kick-line-judge.html?ito=feeds-newsxml Argentine tennis player David Nalbandian booted out of Queen's Club final after wild kick at line judge | Mail Online] *In 2017 [[Denis Shapovalov]] was disqualified after hitting the chair umpire with a ball hit in anger. ==See also== *[[Unsportsmanlike conduct]] *[[List of tennis violations]] ==References== {{Portal|Tennis}} {{Tennis box}} [[Category:Sports penalties]] [[Category:Tennis terminology]]

'''Dual player'''The History of the Gaelic Athletic Association in Canada John O'Flynn, Ainsley Baldwin - 2008 "Mike's hurling was Frank Rafter and a notable member, Liam Cotter, a dual player, who helpedto write the constitution for the Toronto GAA." or '''dual star'''{{cite web|url=https://www.joe.ie/uncategorized/sean-og-to-be-given-freedom-of-cork-city/23673 |accessdate=2 December 2016|title=Seán Óg to be given freedom of Cork city |date=27 Apr 2011 |quote=The 33-year old dual star, who won three All-Ireland hurling titles and ... Taoiseach and fellow dual star Jack Lynch, athlete Sonia O'Sullivan|website=[[JOE.ie]]}} is a term used in [[Irish English]] to describe someone who competes in multiple sports - for example in Victorian Ireland [[cricket]] and [[hurling]].''Sport and society in Victorian Ireland: the case of Westmeath'' Page 157 Tom Hunt - 2007 "The dual player was also common in Kilkenny cricket and hurling circles. ... In 1887 the Kells GAA club played a cricket match against Gaulstown of Tullaroan" The term today in [[Gaelic games]] typically describes a male player who plays both [[Gaelic football]] and [[hurling]] or, if a female player, a player of [[ladies' Gaelic football]] and [[camogie]]. The player does not necessarily have to play at the same standard in both sports. The number of dual stars at county level has decreased recently due to the increasing demands placed upon the best players of both sports. ==Examples== {{further|:Category:Dual players}} ==List of dual players with All-Ireland titles== {|align=top class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="darkgray" !Name !Team(s) ![[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|All-Ireland SHC titles]] ![[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship|All-Ireland SFC titles]] |- | [[Alan Kerins|Kerins, Alan]] || [[Galway GAA|Galway]] || — || 2001 |- | [[Jimmy Barry-Murphy|Barry-Murphy, Jimmy]]''Irish Almanac and Yearbook of Facts 1997'' Page 298 Pat McArt, Donal Campbell - 1997 "GAA Barry-Murphy, Jimmy: (born Cork, 1954). Outstanding dual player who won six All-Ireland medals, one in football (1973) and five in hurling (between 1976 and 1986). His other achievements are almost as breathtaking, two All-Ireland.."|| [[Cork GAA|Cork]] || 1976, 1977, 1978, 1984, 1986 || 1973 |- | [[Derry Beckett|Beckett, Derry]] || Cork || 1942 || 1945 |- | [[Greg Blaney|Blaney, Greg]] || [[Down GAA|Down]]
|| — || 1991, 1994 |- | [[Frank Burke (dual player)|Burke, Frank]] || [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] || 1917, 1920 || 1921, 1922, 1923 |- | [[Pádraic Collins|Collins, Podge]] || [[Clare GAA|Clare]] || [[2013 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|2013]] || — |- | Collins, Seán || [[Clare GAA|Clare]] || [[2013 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|2013]] || — |- | [[Denis Coughlan|Coughlan, Denis]] || Cork || 1976, 1977, 1978 || 1973 |- | [[Brendan Cummins (Tipperary hurler)|Cummins, Brendan]] || [[Tipperary GAA|Tipperary]] || 2001, 2010 || — |- | [[Ray Cummins|Cummins, Ray]]Declan Hassett ''Passing through'' Page 148 2004 "I saw Jack Lynch play at the very end of his career but cannot now recall those games too clearly. For many, Jack would be the greatest dual player of all time. For me, the greatest dualist remains Ray Cummins." || Cork || 1970, 1976, 1977, 1978||1973 |- | [[Liam Currams|Currams, Liam]] || [[Offaly GAA|Offaly]] || 1981 || 1982 |- | [[Des Ferguson|Ferguson, Des]] || [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] || —|| 1958, 1963 |- | [[Lar Foley|Foley, Lar]] || [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] || —|| 1958, 1963 |- | [[Pierce Grace|Grace, Pierce]] || Dublin
[[Kilkenny GAA|Kilkenny]] || 1911, 1912, 1913 || 1906, 1907 |- | [[Jack Lynch|Lynch, Jack]] || Cork || 1941, 1942, 1943, 1944, 1946 || 1945 |- | [[Billy Mackessy|Mackessy, Billy]] || Cork || 1903 || 1911 |- | [[Teddy McCarthy|McCarthy, Teddy]] || Cork || 1986, 1990 || 1989, 1990 |- | [[Paddy Mackey|Mackey, Paddy]] || [[Wexford GAA|Wexford]] || 1910 || 1915, 1916, 1917, 1918 |- | [[Liam Markham|Markham, Liam]] || [[Clare GAA|Clare]] || [[2013 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|2013]] || — |- | [[Leonard McGrath|McGrath, Leonard]] || [[Galway GAA|Galway]] || 1923 || 1925 |- | [[Cathal McInerney|McInerney, Cathal]] || [[Clare GAA|Clare]] || [[2013 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|2013]] || — |- | [[Brian Murphy (dual player)|Murphy, Brian]] || Cork || 1976, 1977, 1978 || 1973 |- | [[Seán Óg Ó hAilpín|Ó hAilpín, Seán Óg]][[Irish Examiner]] -2 nov. 2012 "O hAilpin retires from inter-county hurling - "O hAilpin was a talismanic player for Cork throughout his 16-year career, starting-out as a dual player before focusing on his hurling career"|| Cork || [[1999 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|1999]], [[2004 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|2004]], [[2005 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|2005]] || — |- | O'Halloran, Davy || [[Clare GAA|Clare]] || [[2013 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|2013]] || — |- | [[Seán O'Kennedy|O'Kennedy, Seán]] || Wexford || 1910 || 1915, 1916, 1917 |- | O'Neill, Alan || [[Clare GAA|Clare]] || [[2013 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|2013]] || — |- | [[W. J. Spain|Spain, W. J.]] || Dublin
[[Limerick GAA|Limerick]] || 1887 || 1889 |- | [[Denis Walsh|Walsh, Denis]] || Cork || 1986, 1990 || 1989, 1990 |} In 1990, [[Teddy McCarthy]] of Cork became the first player to win both a football ''and'' a hurling All-Ireland in the same year. This unique achievement remains intact as of 2015. Ex-[[Taoiseach]] [[Jack Lynch]] won one football and five hurling All-Irelands with Cork during the 1940s. To this day he is the only player in history to have won All-Ireland senior medals in six consecutive years. ==List of dual players with All Stars in both codes== A few players have won [[GAA GPA All Stars Awards|All Star Awards]] in both codes. These include: * [[Jimmy Barry-Murphy]] * [[Ray Cummins]] * [[Liam Currams]] * [[Brian Murphy (dual player)|Brian Murphy]] Ray Cummins has uniquely won an All Star Award in both hurling and Gaelic football in the same year, 1971. ==Dual county== [[Dual county]] is a similar term for counties that have teams that play at the same level in both football and hurling. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Dual players| ]] [[Category:Gaelic games terminology]]

{{Infobox sport governing body |name= Egyptian Squash Association |logo= Logo_Egyptian_Squash_Association.jpg |logosize= 180px |sport= [[Squash (sport)|Squash]] |abbrev = |founded = 1991 |aff = |affdate = |region = [[Squash Federation of Africa]] |regionyear = |location = [[Nasr City]], [[Cairo]] |president = Assem Khalifa |chairman = Sayed El Kamash |chiefexec = |secretary = Dalia Mahmoud Al Hefney
Mona Fawzey |coach = [[Amir Wagih]] |womenscoach = |replaced = |prevfounded = |url = http://www.squashegypt.com/en/ |countryflag= Egypt }} '''Egyptian Squash Association''' is recognised as the [[Egypt]]ian National governing body of the sports of [[Squash (sport)|Squash]]. Egyptian Squash Federation is responsible for the following tasks:[http://www.squashegypt.com/en/about-us www.squashegypt.com/en/about-us] * Decide public policies that lead to the deployment of the squash in the Arab Republic of Egypt and upgradable. Administration of the squash from the technical aspects, financial and regulatory Puts the different competitions, championships and oversee their implementation. * Development of the rules governing the affairs of the training and arbitration as well as terms and conditions that must be met by the coaches and referees. * Preservation of the rules and principles of the international game of squash and protect the hobby. * The preparation of national teams that represent Egypt in all international forums. * Approval and registration of players enrolled in Egyptian Squash Federation. * Sets rules and regulations governing the transfers of players. * Support the Egyptian representation in international federations, continental and regional presence to ensure that the Egyptian Work on the development of resources Alatha. ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[Squash in Egypt]] * [[Egypt men's national squash team]] * [[Egypt women's national squash team]] {{Sports governing bodies in Egypt}} {{National Members of the World Squash Federation Federation}} [[Category:Squash in Egypt]] [[Category:National members of the World Squash Federation]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Egypt|Squash]] {{squash-stub}} {{Egypt-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Estadio Eduardo Santos | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = InteriorEstadioEduardoSantos.JPG | image_size = 250px | caption = Estadio Eduardo Santos | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Santa Marta]], [[Colombia]] | coordinates = {{Coord|11.2398262|-74.1951263|display=inline,title|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | built = 1951 | opened = 1951 | renovated = | expanded = 1998 | closed = 2013 | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 23,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Unión Magdalena]] }}
'''Estadio Eduardo Santos''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Santa Marta]], [[Colombia]], used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. It is the largest sports facility in [[Magdalena Department]] with a maximum capacity of 23,000 people.<ref name=Aforo>{{cite web |language=es |url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-805500 |title=El Eduardo Santos, con más capacidad |trans-title=The Eduardo Santos, with more capacity |publisher=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]] |date=25 September 1998 |accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref><ref name=Worldstadiums>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/south_america/countries/colombia.shtml |title=Stadiums in Colombia |publisher=Worldstadiums.com |accessdate=22 September 2011}}</ref> The stadium is named after politician and publisher [[Eduardo Santos]], President of the Republic of Colombia from 1938 to 1942.
==Unión Magdalena== Since its opening in 1951, Estadio Eduardo Santos has been home to the [[football (soccer)|football]] club [[Unión Magdalena]], and witnessed the birth of prominent figures of Colombian football, including former captain Colombia Carlos '[[El pibe]]' ('The Kid') Valderrama.<ref name=eltiempo>{{Cite web|language=es|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/caribe/ARTICULO-WEB-PLANTILLA_NOTA_INTERIOR-7661107.html|title=Policía lidera campaña para recuperar el estadio Eduardo Santos, en Santa Marta|trans-title=Police lead campaign to recover Eduardo Santos stadium in Santa Marta|publisher=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]|author=Paola Benjumea Brito |date=23 March 2010 | accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref> In 2002, a monumental sculpture of [[Carlos Valderrama]] was unveiled at the stadium entrance in a grand ceremony with fireworks attended by about 14,000 people, including 3,000 special guests.<ref name=IEDJackeline>{{cite web |language=es|url=http://prezi.com/kloedpkq4nkf/estadio-eduardo-santos|title=ESTADIO EDUARDO SANTOS|publisher=I.E.D Jackeline Kennedy|author=Jonny Parra Sanchez |date=25 March 2014|accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref><ref name=emol>{{cite web |language=es|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/deportes/2002/11/24/99212/levantan-monumento-en-honor-a-carlos-valderrama.html|title=Levantan monumento en honor a Carlos Valderrama|trans-title=Monument erected in honor of Carlos Valderrama|publisher=[[El Mercurio]] Online ([[emol]]) |date=24 November 2002|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> The 6.5 meter high, eight ton monument sculpted by [[Amilkar Ariza]], is considered the world's largest bronze for a footballer.<ref name=IEDJackeline/><ref name=emol/><ref name=Ariza>{{cite web |language=es|url=http://www.fundacionamilkarariza.org/Pibe.php|title=Escultura Monumental Del "Pibe" Valderrama|trans-title=Monumental Sculpture of "El Pibe" Valderrama|publisher=Fundación Amilkar Ariza|author=[[Amilkar Ariza]]|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> It has become the most visited sculpture in Santa Marta.<ref name=IEDJackeline/><ref name=Ariza/>
In 1968, with a final game against [[Deportivo Cali]] played in the Eduardo Santos Stadium, [[Union Magdalena]] won its first and only Colombian [[football (soccer)|Football]] League Championship to date. During the celebration a motor vehicle accident took the life of a fan in the caravan of triumph, and it is said that Magdalena can never again rise to champion due to the "''Curse of the Celebration.''”<ref name=magdalenaBlog>{{cite web |language=es|url=http://uninmagdalena.blogspot.com/p/origen.html|title=Origen: Campeonato colombiano 1968|trans-title=Origin: Colombian Championship 1968|publisher=uninmagdalena.blogspot.com|accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref>
==Renovations== '''1998''' - With an investment of 340 million pesos, the capacity of the stadium's South Stand was increased by 3,700 spectators.<ref name=Aforo/><ref name=IEDJackeline/>
'''2008''' - A government initiative to restructure the system was launched in response to poor stadium conditions that had resulted from years of neglect.<ref Name=eltiempo/>
'''2013''' - On March 3, the [[Unión Magdalena]] played their last game in the stadium against [[Llaneros F.C.|Llaneros FC]], in compliance with the order to permanently close the Eduardo Santos due to precarious safety conditions for those attending.<ref name=IEDJackeline/> Plans were announced for an investment of 20,000 million pesos in a new stadium Eduardo Santos on the same site, with input from the National Government.<ref name=NuevoEstadio>{{cite web |language=es|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-12668943|title=Nuevo estadio Eduardo Santos irá a concurso|trans-title=Competition for construction of New Eduardo Santos Stadium|publisher=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]|author=REDACCIÓN SANTA MARTA |date=3 September 2013|accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref>
'''2014''' - Plans are in progress to construct the new [[football (soccer)|football]] stadium in time for the [[Bolivarian Games]] 2017.<ref name=elinformador>{{cite web|language=es|url=http://www.elinformador.com.co/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=66287:concurrida-asistencia-de-los-samarios-a-la-caravana-de-la-victoria&catid=118:otros-deportes&Itemid=471 | title=Concurrida asistencia de los samarios a la caravana de la victoria |trans-title=Crowds support samarios victory caravan| publisher=elinformador.com.co|author=Rosa Mendoza Suarez|date=19 November 2013 |accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref><ref name=DeportivaBolivariana>{{cite web |language=es|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-13354028|title=Santa Marta avanza en plataforma hacia Juegos Bolivarianos|trans-title=Santa Marta advances platform for Bolivarian games|publisher=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]|author=Paola Benjumea Brito|date=11 January 2014|accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref> The new stadium is to be relocated to the Villa Deportiva Bolivariana.<ref name=DeportivaBolivariana /> A center for indoor sports such as gymnastics, boxing, and weightlifting is to be built at the current site of Estadio Eduardo Santos, which will be demolished due to deterioration of its physical infrastructure.<ref name=DeportivaBolivariana />

'''Flying disc games''' are [[game]]s played with [[flying disc|disc]]s, often called by the trademarked name [[Frisbee]]s. [[Ultimate (sport)|Ultimate]] and [[disc golf]] are [[sports]] with substantial international followings. [[File:Westenberg.jpg|220px|thumb|right|A semi-professional ultimate game in North America]]
==History== {{Main|Ken Westerfield|Flying disc freestyle}} The flying disc was developed in 1948 by [[Walter Frederick Morrison|Walter Morrison]]. In 1957 January 13, [[Wham-O]] bought the rights to the invention and released it later under the trademarked name [[Frisbee]].
Although playing catch with discs as a pastime and proto-golf games are documented from the early 1900s, and doubtlessly has occurred from time to time before, disc sports began to flower in the late 1960s. As numbers of young people became alienated from social norms, they resisted and looked for alternative recreational activities, including that of throwing a frisbee.<ref>{{cite book|title=Countercultural Sports in America: The History and Meaning of Ultimate Frisbee|url=https://www.amazon.com/Countercultural-Sports-America-History-Ultimate/dp/3838311957|author=Jordan Holtzman-Conston |publisher=Waltham, Mass|year= 2010|accessdate=6 November 2013}}</ref> What started with a few players, in the sixties, like Victor Malafronte, Z Weyand and [[Ken Westerfield]] experimenting with new ways of throwing and catching a disc, later would become known as playing [[Flying disc freestyle|disc freestyle]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Freestyle Players Hall of Fame|url=http://www.freestyledisc.org/hall-of-fame/|work=Inductees|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}</ref> Organized disc sports, in the 1970s, began with promotional efforts from [[Wham-O]] and [[Irwin Toy]] (Canada). These took the form of [[Frisbee#Disc sports|national tournaments]] and Frisbee show tours at universities, fairs and sporting events. Disc sports such as [[Flying disc freestyle|freestyle]], [[double disc court]], [[Guts (game)|guts]], [[Ultimate (sport)|ultimate]] and [[disc golf]] became this sports first events.<ref>{{cite web|title=World Flying Disc Federation|url=http://wfdf.org/|work=WFDF Official Website|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=World Flying Disc Federation|url=http://wfdf.org/history-stats/history-of-fyling-disc|work=History of the Flying Disc|accessdate=October 20, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019095944/http://wfdf.org/history-stats/history-of-fyling-disc|archivedate=October 19, 2013|df=}}</ref> Two sports, the team sport of [[Ultimate (sport)|ultimate]] and [[disc golf]] are very popular worldwide and are now being played semi-professionally.<ref>{{cite web|title=Professional Disc Golf Association|url=http://www.pdga.com/|work=PDGA Official Website|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=American Ultimate Disc League|url=http://theaudl.com/|work=AUDL Official Website|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref> The [[World Flying Disc Federation]], [[Professional Disc Golf Association]], and the Freestyle Players Association, are the official sanctioning organizations for disc sports worldwide.
[[Guts (game)|Guts]] was invented by the Healy Brothers in the 1950s and developed at the International Frisbee Tournament (IFT) in [[Marquette, Michigan]]. [[Ultimate (sport)|Ultimate]], the most widely played disc sport, began in the late 1960s with [[Joel Silver]] and Jared Kass. In the 1970s it developed as an organized sport with the creation of the [[Ultimate Players Association]] with Dan Roddick, Tom Kennedy and Irv Kalb. [[Double disc court]] was invented and introduced in the early 1970s by Jim Palmeri. In 1974, [[Flying disc freestyle|freestyle]] competition was created and introduced by [[Ken Westerfield]] and [[Discraft]]s Jim Kenner.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Frisbee and Flying Disc freestyle|work=Formative Years|url=http://www.freestyledisc.org/freestyle-history/#chapter2|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> Judging standards were developed by the Freestyle Players Association. In 1976, the game of [[disc golf]] was standardized with targets called "pole holes" invented and developed by [[Wham-O]]'s Ed Headrick and the [[Professional Disc Golf Association]].<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Ultimate Frisbee and Disc Sports|url=https://ultimatediscsport.com/|accessdate=December 25, 2017}}</ref>
Beginning in 1974, the International Frisbee Association (IFA), under the direction of Dan Roddick, became the regulatory organization for all of these sports.
==Ultimate== [[File:Ultimate field.svg|360px|thumb|right|Ultimate playing field]] {{main|Ultimate (sport)}} Ultimate (also called Ultimate Frisbee) is a competitive non-contact [[team sport|team]] [[sport]]. The object of the game is to score points by passing the disc to a team member in the opposing teams end zone. Players may not run while holding the disc. Catching is done with one hand or both hands on the rim or hands simultaneously on the top and bottom sometimes referred to as a clap-catch. When one-hand catching on the rim, care must always be taken in hand placement and making sure to catch on the correct side of the disc, according to which way the disc is spinning. One side will tend to spin out of your hand, while the other side will spin into your hand, making for a more secure catch. Many players avoid this problem by always catching with both hands when possible. The most popular throws used in a game of ultimate are [[Flying disc techniques#Techniques|backhand, sidearm/forehand, hammer and scoober]]. Being a deep threat with multiple throwing techniques and the ability to pass the disc before the defense has had a chance to re-set, is always optimal. Some players use a throw and catch [[Flying disc freestyle|freestyle]] practice to help improve their ultimate handling skills.<ref>{{cite web|title=Freestyle the Ultimate Edge|url=http://www.ultimaterob.com/2014/08/25/freestyle-the-ultimate-edge/|accessdate=November 13, 2015}}</ref> The game was invented in 1968 as an evening pastime by Jared Kass. Ultimate is distinguished by its [[Ultimate (sport)#Spirit of the Game|Spirit of the Game]] - the principles of fair play, [[sportsmanship]], and the joy of play. [[USA Ultimate]] and [[Ultimate Canada]] are the rules and sanctioning organizations for ultimate in the US and Canada. The [[American Ultimate Disc League]] (AUDL) and [[Major League Ultimate]] (MLU) are the first semi professional ultimate leagues. The [[Major League Ultimate]] (MLU) ceased operation on December 21, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ultiworld.com/2016/12/21/breaking-major-league-ultimate-suspends-operations/|title=BREAKING: Major League Ultimate Suspends Operations|date=21 December 2016|last=Eisenhood|first=Charlie|work=Ultiworld}}</ref>
===Games based on Ultimate=== [[Image:Schtick Disc Field Diagram.png|right|thumb|488px|The Schtick Disc field, showing opposing team territories and scoreboxes.]] A number of games have evolved which are derived or similar to Ultimate, but played with different rules. These games are often played when available fields or teams are too small for a full sized ultimate game.
{| class="wikitable" |- !Game !Description |- |[[Goaltimate]] |a half-court flying disc game derived from ultimate, similar to Hot Box |- |[[Hot box (game)|Hot box]] |a non-contact team sport which is similar to Ultimate, but played on a smaller field and with fewer players |- |Mini ultimate |a high energy, predominantly urban sport played on a smaller field than ultimate |- |D-Hoops |also known as Disc basketball is a flying disc sport played on a regulation basketball court to specified rules.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dischooprim.com/rules.html|title=Rules|publisher=|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> |- |Schtick disc |an Ultimate variant played with two discs where running with the disc is allowed;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://schtickdisc.org/|title=Home at schtickdisc.org|publisher=|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> generally more forgiving operations of play than most team sports makes the game more fun and accessible to players of varied abilities than traditional ultimate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sotg.ca/variant_games/variant_games.php#J|title=Variant Ultimate Games-several variations of flying disc (Frisbee) games|publisher=www.sotg.ca|accessdate=2009-05-25}}</ref> The game was conceived and pioneered by a group of friends from Delaware, USA and/or graduates of Rice University, and was first played in 1994 on [[Assateague Island]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://schtickdisc.org/home/history-of-schtick/|title=History Of Schtick|publisher=www schtickdisc.org|accessdate=2009-05-25}}</ref> It has since been played throughout the US and in Australia as well, having been featured at Sydney's [http://longestday.ultimatefrisbee.org.au/ Longest Day Beach Ultimate Tournament] since 2001. Typically a football half-way line is used to mark the midline, as precise knowledge of the line's position is frequently required for tactical play. Scoreboxes can be marked out by any means that is easily visible, though traditionally bundled socks or knotted rags have been used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://schtickdisc.org/official-rules/|title=Official Rules Of Schtick|publisher=www schtickdisc.org|accessdate=2009-05-26}}</ref> |- |[[Kan-jam]] |is a flying disc game, played with a flying disc and two cans in which you deflect the disc into the can. |}
==Disc Golf== [[File:US Army 51696 The Corps' Black Butte Lake celebrates National Public Lands Day with new disc golf course.jpg|160px|thumb|right|Disc golf pole hole, a standardized disc golf target created by Ed Headrick.]] {{main|Disc golf}} Disc golf is a game based on the rules of [[golf]] (referred to by disc golfers as "ball and stick golf"). It uses discs smaller and denser than an ultimate disc. The discs are [[Flying disc techniques|thrown]] towards a target, which serves as the "hole". The official targets are metal baskets with hanging chains to catch the discs.
==Urban disc golf==
Before there were standardized targets called pole holes, [[disc golf]] used to be played in parks and urban settings using natural objects as targets. In some cases courses were created by the players themselves as they played, with each player taking turns determining targets and throwing designations (mandatories and out of bounds)
==Freestyle play and competition== {{Main|Ken Westerfield|Flying disc freestyle}} [[File:Ken Westerfield Heel Kick.jpg|160px|thumb|left|[[Ken Westerfield]], playing freestyle, 1960s-70s.]] Disc freestyle, also known as freestyle Frisbee in reference to the trademarked brand name, is a sport and performing art characterized by creative, acrobatic, and athletic maneuvers with a flying disc. Freestyle is performed individually or more commonly in groups, both competitively and recreationally. Freestyle, in the early 1970s, before the invention of the "nail-delay", catching possibilities would depend on the throw you were given, it was always spontaneous and unpredictable. Play of this type of freestyle was performed with two players standing 30-40 yards apart, the throws were fast and varied and the catches were right off the throw, except for the occasional kick or slap-up and rarely a pause between the catch and the throw back. At advanced levels, the throws and catches would become a flow that was created once you mastered the basics. It was fast and fluid and visibly would resemble martial arts and dance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Decade Awards Pre-Modern|url=http://freestyle-frisbee.com/skippy/1970s_pre_modern.html|work=Freestyle History|accessdate=January 20, 2015}}</ref> Most competitive freestyle today centers around the [[Flying disc freestyle#Basic maneuvers|nail-delay]] with many players using what are called [[Flying disc freestyle#Getting started|delay-aids]] (plastic nails and silicone sprays).
Many players of other disc sports will often use a throw and catch (no plastic nails or sprays) version of freestyle, to warm up for their disc games. Ultimate disc players often use freestyle to improve their throwing and catching skills as well as a good way to add focus and flexibility to their game.<ref>{{cite web|title=Freestyle the Ultimate Edge|url=http://www.ultimaterob.com/2014/08/25/freestyle-the-ultimate-edge/|accessdate=December 3, 2014}}</ref>
[[Flying disc freestyle|Freestyle]] competition is an event where teams of two or three players perform a routine which consists of a series of creative throwing and catching techniques set to music. The routine is judged on the basis of difficulty, execution and presentation. The team with the best total score is declared the winner.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sanchez|first=Rodney and Bethany|title=Freestyle Frisbee Basics|url=http://freestyledisc.org/learnToPlay.html|accessdate=28 October 2012|newspaper=Freestyle Players Association|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109224407/http://www.freestyledisc.org/learnToPlay.html|archive-date=9 November 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 1974, [[Ken Westerfield]] and Jim Kenner (founder and CEO of [[Discraft]]),<ref>{{cite web|title=Freestyle|url=http://www.discraft.com/freestyle.html|work=Discraft Freestyle|accessdate=October 28, 2012}}</ref> introduce and win the first [[flying disc freestyle]] competition at the 3rd annual [[Ken Westerfield#The Canadian Open Championships and the first Frisbee freestyle competition|Canadian Open Frisbee Championships]], [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada and the Vancouver Open Frisbee Championships.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ira's Abs Athletic Challenges and Achievements|url=http://www.irasabs.com/?tag=ken-westerfield|work=Ken Westerfield Frisbee Pioneer|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Best Freestyle Routine|url=http://freestyle-frisbee.com/skippy/1970s_pre_modern.html#pairs_routine|work=The Decade Awards 1970-75 Top Routine|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> These were the first Frisbee freestyle competitions.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Frisbee and Flying Disc freestyle|work=Development of Frisbee in Canada|url=http://www.freestyledisc.org/freestyle-history/#appendix1|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
A year later the American Flying Disc Open (AFDO) [[Rochester, New York]], the Octad in [[New Brunswick, New Jersey]] and the 1975 World Frisbee Championships, held at the Rose Bowl in [[Pasadena, California]], adopted Westerfield and Kenners freestyle competition format as one of their events. Today this same freestyle event is now accepted as one of the premier events in [[Flying disc]] tournaments worldwide.
The Freestyle Players Association was formed to oversee the competitive aspects of freestyle frisbee, and to help new players learn how to freestyle.<ref>{{cite web|title=Freestyle Players Association|work=About Freestyle|url=http://www.freestyledisc.org/sport|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
==Guts== {{main|Guts (game)}} Guts or Guts Frisbee is a disc sport inspired by dodgeball, involving teams throwing a flying disc (rather than balls) at members of the opposing team. One to five team members stand in a line facing the opposing team across the court, with the two teams lined up parallel to each other. Which team begins play is determined "flipping the disc", an action similar to a coin toss, but using the disc itself. One member of the team is then selected to start play.[[File:Pascal bid.jpg|250px|thumb|left|Guts Frisbee is the oldest disc sport (1957)]] That member then raises an arm to indicate readiness to throw, at which point the members of the opposing team freeze in position. If the thrower misses the "scoring area" (a demarcated area a bit larger than the space occupied by the opposing team), the receiving team scores a point. If a member of the receiving team catches the disc cleanly, neither team scores a point. If the throw is within the scoring area and the receiving team fails to catch, or catches but drops the disc, the throwing team gets a point. The receiving team then picks up the disc and becomes the throwing team. The receiving team must catch the disc cleanly in one hand, and may not move from position until after the disc leaves the hand of the thrower. The disc may not be trapped between the hand and any other part of the body, including the other hand. This frequently results in a challenging sequence of "tips" or "bobbles", which are rebounds of the disc off of receivers' hands or body to slow the disc down and keep it in play until it can be caught. This often involves multiple players on the receiving team. Play continues until at least 21 points have been scored by one of the teams and there is a difference in score of at least 2 points.
==Double Disc Court==
[[File:DDC field.png|340px|thumb|right|The Double Disc Court field]] Double disc court (DDC) invented and introduced by [[Frisbee]] Hall of Fame inductee Jim Palmeri of [[Rochester, NY]], is a sport played with two [[flying disc]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jim Palmeri|url=http://www.gutsfrisbee.com/hall-of-fame/1984/jim-palmeri|work=Hall of Fame|accessdate=January 1, 2014}}</ref> Two teams of two players each stand in their own courts. The goal is to defend a court from an attack by the opposing team. Two identical square courts are located on a level playing field of grass measuring 13 meters on a side. The distance between the courts is 17 meters. Attacks are made in two ways: by throwing a disc in play into the opponents' court in an attempt to have the disc come to rest within that court without ever having touched out-of-bounds, or by causing both discs to be touched by a player or players on the opposing team at the same time (called a "double"). A team scores a point whenever they make a successful attack or whenever an opponent throws a disc out-of-bounds. The first team to score the requisite number of points as determined by the competitive format wins the game.
==Canine Disc== {{main|Disc dog}} Canine Disc (or dog disc) is a dog sport and a disc sport. In canine disc competitions, dogs and their human flying disc throwers compete in events such as distance catching and somewhat choreographed freestyle catching. The sport celebrates the bond between handler and dog, by allowing them to work together.
==Disc games adapted from non-disc games==
These games originated when the rules of another game were adjusted to use a flying disc in place of a ball.
{| class="wikitable" |- !Game !Description |- |[[Guts (game)|Guts]] and [[dodge disc]] |Variations of [[dodgeball]] using a flying disc in place of the ball or balls |- |Crosbee |adapted from [[lacrosse]], it is in many ways a cross between [[Touch football (American)|touch football]] and ultimate<ref>{{cite web|author=DougyD |url=http://crosbee.blogspot.com/ |title=Crosbee - a Frisbee game |publisher=Crosbee.blogspot.com |date=2008-08-16 |accessdate=2013-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=YlhMWut-nJ4C&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=crosbee+frisbee | title = Games 2 | isbn = 9780310220312 | author1 = Specialties | first1 = Youth | year = 1997}}</ref> |- |[[500 (ball game)|500]] |Can also be played with a football or other ball. One player throws the disk to the other players and calls out a number between 0 and 500. The catcher wins that number of points, and the first player to earn 500 is the new thrower. |}
==Other/unclassified games== * [[Flutterguts]] — a game used mainly to practice catching flying discs * [[Kan-jam]] - a variation of horseshoes. * [[Polish horseshoes]] - similar to Fricket, but with one pole on each end, with a bottle upright on top of each one (also known as Beersbee) * [[D-Hoops]] - a variation of Ultimate and basketball<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dischooprim.com/rules.html|title=Rules|publisher=|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vicksburgpost.com/2014/06/16/vicksburg-man-gets-patent-for-disc-sports-equipment/|title=Vicksburg man gets patent for disc sports equipment - The Vicksburg Post|publisher=|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> * [[Friskee]] - a game with 2 28inch goals, 2 teams and 1 frisbee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://friskee.de/ccms|title=the german Friskee Association|publisher=Oliver Hofmann und Alexander Kuhnen|accessdate=12 May 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Disc golf]] * [[Ultimate Canada]] * [[Ultimate (sport)]] * [[Disc dog]] * [[Guts (game)]] * [[Flying disc techniques]] * [[Flying disc freestyle]] * [[Ken Westerfield]]
==External links== * [http://www.freestyledisc.org/freestyle-history/ History of Early Frisbee Sport] * [http://www.wfdf.org/index.php?page=rules/art2.htm Official Rules for Double Disc Court] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070205112941/http://www.pellucid.com/conrad/ddc/ Additional information and player rankings for Double Disc Court] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nszaRylOxus How To Play Double Disc Court (DDC)] Instructional Video * [http://gutsfrisbee.com Guts Frisbee] * [https://ultimatediscsport.com/ History of Ultimate Frisbee and Disc Sports in the U.S. and Canada]
==References== <references/>
