at [[Target Field (Metro Transit station)|Target Field station]] | address = 1 Twins Way | construction_cost = US$555 million{{cite web |title=Minnesota Ballpark Authority|url=http://www.ballparkauthority.com/Budget.html|publisher=Minnesota Ballpark Authority|date=|accessdate=April 19, 2017}} | former_names = | website = http://www.mlb.com/twins/ballpark/ | seating_capacity = 39,504 (2010–2012){{cite news|title=Target Field|url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/twins/84925462.html?elr=KArksLckD8EQDUoaEyqyP4O:DW3ckUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aUUsZ|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=February 22, 2010|accessdate=February 22, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100223072911/http://www.startribune.com/sports/twins/84925462.html?elr=KArksLckD8EQDUoaEyqyP4O:DW3ckUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aUUsZ|archivedate=February 23, 2010|df=mdy-all}}
39,021 (2013–2015){{cite news |title=American League Team Notes|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/alnotes.htm|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=December 31, 2012|accessdate=March 7, 2013}}
38,871 (2016){{cite web |title=2016 Minnesota Twins Media Guide|url=http://twinstrivia.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/2016-Twins-Media-Guide-early.pdf|publisher=Major League Baseball Advanced Media|date=February 17, 2016|accessdate=March 28, 2016|page=386}}
38,885 (2017){{cite web |title=2017 Minnesota Twins Media Guide|url=http://twinstrivia.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/2017-Twins-Media-Guide-updated02152017.pdf|publisher=Major League Baseball Advanced Media|date=February 15, 2017|accessdate=February 18, 2017|page=388}}
38,649 (2018–present){{cite news |title= Suspended Jorge Polanco Speaks to His Twins Teammates |first= La Velle E. |last= Neal III |url= http://www.startribune.com/suspended-jorge-polanco-speaks-to-his-twins-teammates/477583143 |newspaper= [[Star Tribune]] |location= Minneapolis |date= March 22, 2018 |accessdate= May 23, 2018}} }} '''Target Field''' is a [[baseball park]] in the [[North Loop, Minneapolis|historic warehouse (or North Loop) district]] of downtown [[Minneapolis]]. It is the home ballpark of the [[Minnesota Twins]], the state's [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) franchise. It also has served as the occasional home of [[Minnesota Golden Gophers baseball]], and other local and regional baseball events. The ballpark officially opened with a capacity of 39,504 on April 12, 2010, and has since hosted the [[2014 Major League Baseball All-Star Game]].{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120829&content_id=37546072&vkey=pr_mlb&c_id=mlb|title=Minnesota Twins awarded the 2014 All-Star Game|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|accessdate=September 18, 2012}} It is an open-air ballpark, and not considered "roof-ready" in any way. Though designed as a baseball venue, it can accommodate football, soccer, and outdoor concerts. Its extensive banquet and conference facilities are marketed for corporate and other non-Twins and non-baseball events. In 2010, ''[[ESPN The Magazine]]'' ranked Target Field as the #1 baseball stadium experience in North America.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/sportsnation/teamrankings/_/category/stx#table|title=Ultimate Team Rankings|work=ESPN The Magazine|accessdate=May 18, 2011}} ==Summary== [[File:Target Field April 2010.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Target Field during a game vs. Kansas City in 2010]] Target Field is the Twins/Senators sixth ballpark, and the franchise's third in Minnesota. The Twins had played 28 seasons at the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]], and before that 21 seasons at [[Metropolitan Stadium]]. The Twins shared both facilities with the [[Minnesota Vikings]], and the Metrodome with the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|University of Minnesota Golden Gophers football team]]. The final budget for construction was $435 million, of which $175 million was paid by the Twins and $260 million was paid by [[Hennepin County, Minnesota|Hennepin County]] by way of a 0.15% county-wide sales tax. An additional $120 million in infrastructure costs were split between the county ($90 million), the team ($20 million), [[Target Corporation]] ($4.5 million), the [[Minnesota Department of Transportation]] ($3.5 million) and the Minnesota Ballpark Authority ($2 million) bringing the project's total cost to US$555 million.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ballparkauthority.com/Budget.html|title=Target Field Construction Budget - Minnesota Ballpark Authority|website=www.ballparkauthority.com|language=en|accessdate=April 19, 2017}} [[File:Target Field.jpg|thumb|Armed Services Appreciation Day, on July 3, 2011. The Twins set a three-game series attendance record (123,385) against the Milwaukee Brewers.]] ==History== === Background === The Twins were in their 13th season in the Metrodome when they formally declared their desire to find a new home on July 18, 1994. [[Carl Pohlad]], owner of the Twins, told the [[Metropolitan Sports Facilities Commission]] (owners of the Metrodome) the current facility was "economically obsolete" due to changes in the economy of Major League Baseball.{{Cite book|title=Target Field|last=Berg|first=Steve|publisher=MVP Books|year=2010|isbn=978-0-7603-3842-1|location=Minneapolis, MN|pages=49-71}} This declaration started a process which would culminate nearly 16 years later with the opening of Target Field. In the intervening years, many ideas, financing plans and possible locations came and went. The long process included threats of relocation, infighting between the [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul|Twin Cities]] of [[Minneapolis]] and [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul]], and numerous pieces of legislation (both passed and not passed) at various levels of government. The process spanned the terms of three [[List of Governors of Minnesota|Minnesota governors]], five mayors of [[List of mayors of Minneapolis|Minneapolis]] or [[List of mayors of Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul]], and even two long-tenured [[List of Minnesota Twins managers|Twins managers]]. === Timeline === {{Cite web|url=https://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/issues/issues?issue=baseball|title=Baseball Stadiums (A concise summary of legislative action on Minnesota baseball facilities)|last=|first=|date=September 2014|website=Minnesota Legislative Reference Library|access-date=}} {{prose|section|date=December 2017}} 1961 – The original Washington Senators become the Minnesota Twins, and move to Metropolitan Stadium 1982 – Twins move to HHH Metrodome 1984 – [[Calvin Griffith]] sells Twins to Carl Pohlad 1994 – Pohlad declares Metrodome “economically obsolete” 1996 – First new ballpark plan fails to win support 1997 – Second new ballpark plan fails to win support; Minneapolis stadium contributions capped by referendum 1998 – Referendum to build ballpark in Greensboro, NC fails 1999 – Referendum to build ballpark in St. Paul, MN fails 2000 – Eventual site of Target Field identified 2001 – Twins become part of MLB’s “contraction” plans 2002 – Hennepin County makes its first financing proposal; St. Paul options eliminated 2005 – Twins and Hennepin County reach financing agreement 2006 – Ballpark legislation enacted 2007 – Construction begins, land dispute settled 2010 – Twins move to Target Field === Early plans (1994-1999) === Immediately following Pohlad's 1994 declaration of intent, the Twins began making plans to build a new, retractable-roof stadium on a site just north of the Metrodome.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J_n-tQUGWEkC&lpg=PA240-IA12&ots=D_ABd3Qjt-&dq=twins%20retractable%20mississippi%201997&pg=PA240-IA12#v=onepage&q=twins%20retractable%20mississippi%201997&f=false|title=Stadium Games: Fifty Years of Big League Greed and Bush League Boondoggles|last=Weiner|first=Jay|date=January 1, 2000 |publisher=U of Minnesota Press|isbn=9780816634354|language=en}} Extensive conceptual work went into the site and stadium. At that time, the [https://www.google.com/maps/@44.9770583,-93.2544665,17.75z desired site] was largely underused as surface parking, despite being adjacent to the Mississippi River, and located in the city's [[Mill District, Minneapolis|historic milling district]]. It included land which would be used for the [[Guthrie Theater]] (2006), [[Gold Medal Park]] (2007), and high-end housing. ==== 1996 ==== The riverfront plan formed the basis for all of the early discussions, and was first presented to the Minnesota Legislature during the [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/timecapsule/session?sess=79 1996 session]. It did not pass, largely due to widespread public sentiment that Pohlad, Minnesota's second most wealthy citizen, should pay for a new facility himself.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J_n-tQUGWEkC&lpg=PA234&ots=D_ABe0Xev2&dq=1996%20pohlad&pg=PA215#v=onepage&q=1996%20pohlad&f=false|title=Stadium Games: Fifty Years of Big League Greed and Bush League Boondoggles|last=Weiner|first=Jay|date=January 1, 2000 |publisher=U of Minnesota Press|isbn=9780816634354|language=en}} ==== 1997 ==== After that failure, private negotiations between Pohlad and [[Arne Carlson|Governor Arne Carlson]] yielded a deal which was brought to the [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/timecapsule/session?sess=80 1997 legislative session]. The Twins had agreed to make an up-front financial contribution to kick-start the project, as well as sell 49% of team ownership to the state. This plan unraveled when local media reported that the complicated "contribution" to be made by the team amounted to a loan from Pohlad which was to be repaid with interest. Public outrage made passing this plan impossible.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J_n-tQUGWEkC&lpg=PA234&ots=D_ABe0Xev2&dq=1996%20pohlad&pg=PA224#v=onepage&q=1996%20pohlad&f=false|title=Stadium Games: Fifty Years of Big League Greed and Bush League Boondoggles|last=Weiner|first=Jay |date=January 1, 2000 |publisher=U of Minnesota Press|isbn=9780816634354|language=en}} Later that same year, the voters in Minneapolis overwhelmingly approved a referendum which prevented the city of Minneapolis from ever spending more than $10 million on a professional sports facility without approval from voters. This effectively removed the city from consideration as a financial partner for a new Twins ballpark.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/05/us/the-1997-elections-referendums-oregon-stays-with-its-law-on-suicides.html|title=THE 1997 ELECTIONS: REFERENDUMS; Oregon Stays With Its Law On Suicides|last=Ayres|first=B. Drummond|date=November 5, 1997 |work=The New York Times|accessdate=April 19, 2017 |issn=0362-4331}} ==== 1998 ==== Meanwhile, the Twins’ Metrodome lease was set to expire in 1998. Governor Carlson felt the issue pressing enough that he called a special session of the Minnesota Legislature for that fall. In advance of the session, Pohlad announced he had signed a letter of intent to sell the team to a potential ownership group in North Carolina ([[Piedmont Triad]]) led by [http://businessnc.com/don-beaver/ Don Beaver].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/04/sports/baseball-playoffs-notes.html|title=BASEBALL PLAYOFFS; NOTES|date=October 4, 1997 |work=The New York Times|accessdate=April 19, 2017 |issn=0362-4331}} The sale would be nullified if either a new stadium was approved in Minnesota, or a referendum to build a new stadium in [[Greensboro, North Carolina|Greensboro]] failed. The Minnesota legislature not only defeated the stadium bill, but passed a resolution{{Cite web|url=https://www.revisor.mn.gov/laws/?year=1997&type=3&doctype=Resolution&id=1|title=RESOLUTION 1-S.F.No. 22|last=|first=|date=November 3, 1997|website=Office of the Revisor of Statutes|accessdate=June 10, 2017}} urging Congress to intervene in what it saw to be the worst practices of professional sports. Then, on May 5, 1998, voters in Greensboro rejected the ballpark referendum by a wide margin{{Cite news|url=http://www.wral.com/news/local/story/125654/|title=Guilford-Forsyth Stadium Vote: A Shot Heard Round the State? :: WRAL.com|last=WRAL|date=May 5, 1998 |work=WRAL.com|accessdate=April 19, 2017 |language=en}} and the sale of the team was cancelled. Meanwhile, the public had come to view Pohlad very unfavorably. ==== 1999 ==== St. Paul mayor [[Norm Coleman]] jumped into this void with an enthusiastic pitch to move the Twins to his city.{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/199907/02_jansene_commit-s/index.shtml|title=MPR: St. Paul Takes Lead in Stadium Push|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en|accessdate=April 19, 2017}} Several downtown locations were offered, the most likely option being adjacent to the new [[Xcel Energy Center]] (though another site considered was in the [[Lowertown Historic District (Saint Paul, Minnesota)|Lowertown]] neighborhood, a location which eventually became [[CHS Field]], home of the [[St. Paul Saints]]). A referendum was scheduled to ask St. Paul voters to approve a sales tax increase for the city's contribution to the project, which would have been an open-air ballpark. Once again, Pohlad agreed to "sell" the team contingent upon the outcome of a referendum. This sale would have been to a group led by Minnesota-based billionaires [[Glen Taylor]] and [http://www.espn.com/espn/sportsbusiness/owner?id=Naegele%20Jr. Robert Naegele].{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/199910/08_khoom_pohladsells/index.shtml|title=MPR: Pohlad Agrees to Sell Twins|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en|accessdate=April 19, 2017}} Because Pohlad was so unpopular, it was thought that removing him from the transaction might help the prospects of the referendum, but it did not. On November 2, 1999, St. Paul voters rejected the plan by a large margin and the concept quickly evaporated.{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/199911/03_khoom_stadium/index.shtml|title=MPR: Voters Write Stadium Obituary|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en|accessdate=April 19, 2017}} === Warehouse District site identified (2000) === The threat of the Twins moving to St. Paul had caught the attention of the business community in Minneapolis, which, up to this point, had been largely silent on the issue. During the run-up to the St. Paul referendum in 1999, an independent working group was formed by Minneapolis businessmen Bruce Lambrecht and Rich Pogin, representatives of a group of investors which owned the Rapid Park parking lot in the [[Warehouse District, Minneapolis|historic warehouse district]] on the northern edge of downtown Minneapolis. This group, initially known as Minnesota Urban Ballpark, and later as MN Twinsville, formed with the express purpose of bringing their land into the discussion about sites for a new Twins ballpark. At first, the 8-acre site appeared to be an extremely unlikely location for a modern professional baseball facility. Besides being far smaller than most MLB sites (modern facilities typically require 16-20 acres), it was hemmed in by railroad tracks, a [[Interstate 394|freeway]], and two city streets passing on bridges. Though very near to [[Target Center]], it was also adjacent to the [http://www.hennepin.us/your-government/facilities/hennepin-energy-recovery-center Hennepin Energy Recovery Center] (HERC), more commonly known as the city's "garbage burner," considered by some to be an undesirable neighbor for a ballpark.{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/01/29/draft-study-garbage-burner-wont-harm-fans-at-new-twins-stadium/|title=Draft study: Garbage burner won’t harm fans at new Twins stadium – Twin Cities|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} But the site’s perceived liabilities were easily offset by significant assets. Careful measurements were made by Lambrecht and local architect David Albersman, which proved that there was enough room for a baseball field and the amenities associated with a Major League ballpark. The site was adjacent to three large, underused [http://www.abc-ramps.com/ parking ramps], and at the potential nexus of a light rail line then being planned (ultimately the [[Metro Blue Line (Minnesota)|Metro Transit Blue Line]]), and a commuter rail line also under consideration (the eventual [[Northstar Line]]). It was also controlled by a single owner who would be a willing seller. This fact alone would significantly simplify the process of acquisition by a governmental entity for a large-scale project. Owing largely to these logistical advantages, as well as an expansive view of the Minneapolis skyline, and the persistence of Lambrecht and Pogin's group, this site would eventually come to house Target Field.{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.stthomas.edu/realestate/2011/02/17/the-little-idea-that-could-the-untold-story-about-the-development-of-target-field/|title=The Little Idea That Could: The untold story about the development of Target Field – Real Estate Matters|website=blogs.stthomas.edu|language=en-US|accessdate=April 20, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.targetfieldhistory.com|title=History of Target Field: The Impossible Ballpark|website=www.targetfieldhistory.com|language=en|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} In early 2000, Lambrecht’s group commissioned a visit by [http://populous.com/profile/earl-santee/ Earl Santee] of [[Populous (company)|Populous]] (then known as HOK Sport) to evaluate whether the site had the potential to house Major League Baseball. His visit, independent of the Twins and all government entities, happened with no publicity whatsoever. Santee reviewed the site and reacted with skepticism, but saw no fatal flaws, nothing that made a ballpark impossible.{{Cite web|url=http://www.citypages.com/news/earl-santee-talks-about-his-target-field-architecture-6546199|title=Earl Santee talks about his Target Field architecture {{!}} City Pages|last=Spicer|first=Judd|website=City Pages|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} He agreed to provide the working group with a concept drawing of a ballpark on that site, an image which was first published in August 2000, and quickly became the center of their ultimately successful campaign. As Santee's dramatic drawing became more widely published, and Lambrecht and Pogin ramped up their lobbying efforts, others began to realize the advantages of the site. This included Mark Oyaas, founder of New Ballpark, Inc.,{{Cite web|url=http://www.mnvideovault.org/mvvPlayer/customPlaylist2.php?id=10159&select_index=5&popup=yes#5|title=tpt OnDemand Video: NewsNight Minnesota {{!}} Stadium - Discussion|website=www.mnvideovault.org|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} a separate group of downtown Minneapolis business leaders, who sought to create a private financing plan for a stadium.{{Cite web|url=http://www.savetheminnesotatwins.com/articles/06.06.2000.html|title=Save the Minnesota Twins.com - Articles - Business leaders will propose privately funded ball park|website=www.savetheminnesotatwins.com|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} They quickly settled on Rapid Park as their preferred ballpark site, which enhanced its visibility significantly. The Twins, however, completely ignored Rapid Park, and kept their distance from all of the ad hoc working groups. They would eventually go on record as believing that the Rapid Park site was too small and constrained to house the type of facility they sought to build.{{Cite news|url=http://www.journalmpls.com/news/2002/11/twins-not-set-on-rapid-park-site/|title=Twins not set on Rapid Park site|date=November 19, 2002 |work=The Journal|accessdate=April 20, 2017|language=en-US}} === Committees, contraction and competition (2000-2002) === ==== 2000 ==== No less than three committees were created in 2000 to offer recommendations on how to proceed. The city of Minneapolis created a panel of citizens known as C-17 to consider various financing models. Their [http://www.ballparkmagic.com/_resources/c17report.pdf final report], issued in February 2001, while not specifically recommending a site, heavily featured the concept drawing of the Rapid Park site on multiple pages. The committee recommended that the city continue its discussions with New Ballpark, Inc., in the hopes of finding a private financing solution. Even before the work of the C-17 was complete, another (unnamed) group of staff analysts within city government, working with the Metropolitan Community Development Agency (MCDA), formally recommended the Rapid Park site to the City Council. Simultaneously, the Twins assembled a 130-member advisory group, dubbed Minnesotans for Major League Baseball,{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200101/11_wilcoxenw_stadium/members.shtml|title=MPR: Members of Minnesotans for Major League Baseball|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} which met to discuss possible stadium alternatives. Their deliberations included a meeting with [[Bud Selig]], commissioner of baseball, to discuss economic issues within the sport.{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200007/19_radila_selig/|title=MPR: Stadium Debate Simmers Under Selig's Fire|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} Their final report did not recommend a site (and did not even mention Rapid Park), but did provide advice to the team on how to proceed in winning public approval for any plan.{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/a-minnesota-way-to-keep-major-league-baseball-in-minnesota-prominent-citizens-group-releases-report-on-twins-future-71093117.html|title=A Minnesota Way to Keep Major League Baseball in Minnesota; Prominent Citizens' Group Releases Report on Twins' Future|last=Baseball|first=Minnesotans for Major League|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en |accessdate=April 20, 2017}} Late in 2000, Twins CEO Chris Clouser proposed playing three games in a temporary outdoor stadium to be built adjacent to the [[Mall of America]] in [[Bloomington, Minnesota|Bloomington, MN]]. He hoped to demonstrate the pleasures of outdoor baseball as a way of jump-starting the political process.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/aug/13/sports/sp-3775|title=Twins Would Like a Little Fresh Air|last=STAPLETON|first=ARNIE|date=August 13, 2000 |work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=April 20, 2017 |language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} The proposal ran into problems from insurance companies, the Minnesota Vikings (who stood to lose Metrodome revenue) and Major League Baseball. It was ultimately scrapped. ==== 2001 ==== During the [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/timecapsule/session?sess=82 2001 legislative session], the Twins pushed for a new financing plan based on ideas gleaned from their advisory committee.{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200101/31_mccalluml_stadium/|title=MPR: Legislators Warming to Stadium Idea|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} The $300 million site-neutral plan would have featured a $150 million contribution from the Pohlads, $50 million from private enterprises, and the remaining $100 million in the form of an interest-free loan from the state of Minnesota. Many viewed the deal as significantly better for taxpayers than the 1997 plan. But the details of the financial arrangements once again were very complicated. Ultimately, the proposal fell victim to a political climate filled with distaste for the economics of baseball, general anti-stadium sentiments, and an unrelated budget standoff which nearly shut down the Minnesota government.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/06/29/us/minnesota-lawmakers-rush-to-avoid-a-state-shutdown.html|title=Minnesota Lawmakers Rush To Avoid a State Shutdown|date=June 29, 2001 |work=The New York Times|accessdate=April 20, 2017 |issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200105/21_mccalluml_blamegame/|title=MPR: Lawmakers Cast Blame For Unfinished Business|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} Despite that legislative misfire, in the summer of 2001 the city of Minneapolis became quite serious about the warehouse district site for a ballpark, after selecting the Twins' preferred riverfront site to house the new Guthrie Theater.{{Cite news|url=http://chippewa.com/guthrie-theater-names-french-architect-jean-nouvel-to-build-new/article_6b7a6e54-205d-54c9-95a9-bf7506686dcc.html|title=Guthrie Theater names French architect Jean Nouvel to build new theater center on riverfront|work=Chippewa Herald|accessdate=April 20, 2017 |language=en}} Though no deal was struck to purchase the Rapid Park land at that time, an initial valuation of $10 million was assumed by the city for a roughly 10 acre parcel. Though not a realistic amount, it did fall conveniently within the restrictions of the 1997 referendum. The Twins were not involved in these discussions, and still exhibited no public interest whatsoever in the warehouse district location. The Twins, stung by the repeated rejections, and feeling that they had no real prospects for a new ballpark in the Twin Cities, next became officially associated with Major League Baseball's long-rumored "contraction" plans.{{Cite web|url=http://www.savetheminnesotatwins.com/articles/11.04.2001.3.html|title=Save the Minnesota Twins.com - Articles - Why eliminate Twins? Money and leverage|website=www.savetheminnesotatwins.com |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} On November 6, 2001, MLB owners voted 28-2 to authorize the elimination of two teams, the Twins and the [[Montreal Expos]] (though the teams were not named publicly). The Pohlads were reportedly offered a $250 million check to fold their franchise.{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2014/07/10/contraction-nearly-stole-twins-baseball-from-minnesota/|title=Contraction nearly stole Twins baseball from Minnesota – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} This attempt at placing more pressure on decision-makers ultimately failed -- spectacularly and quickly -- when, a mere 10 days later, [http://www.twincities.com/2007/10/26/judge-who-spared-baseballs-twins-to-retire/ Hennepin County District Court Judge Harry Crump] ruled that the Twins, by virtue of Major League Baseball's federal anti-trust exemption, could not act as a typical business and simply buy out their Metrodome lease. Their standing as a community asset meant that they had an obligation to honor the lease and continue playing.{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/stories/2001-11-16-contraction.htm|title=USATODAY.com - Judge orders Twins to play next season|website=usatoday30.usatoday.com |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} His decision was upheld by the [[Minnesota Court of Appeals]] on January 21, 2002, and the [[Minnesota Supreme Court]] refused to hear an appeal on February 5, 2002, effectively ending contraction as a negotiating tactic (though its echoes would remain until a new labor agreement between MLB and the MLBPA was reached on August 30, 2002).{{Cite web|url=https://www.infoplease.com/spot/contraction-timeline|title=Baseball Contraction Timeline|website=www.infoplease.com|language=en |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} ==== 2002 ==== Even as the Twins were forced to continue playing in 2002, the seeds of the eventual financing solution were sown when [[Hennepin County, Minnesota|Hennepin County]], in which the city of Minneapolis is located, began to express interest in being a financial partner in a ballpark.{{Cite web|url=http://www.savetheminnesotatwins.com/articles/02.19.2002.html|title=Save the Minnesota Twins.com - Articles - Hennepin County chairman to offer Twins ballpark plan|website=www.savetheminnesotatwins.com |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} Unfortunately for the Twins, Minnesota governor [[Jesse Ventura]] wanted to foster competition between the various localities, thinking it would spur more creativity in the structure of any deal.{{Cite web|url=http://www.savetheminnesotatwins.com/articles/03.16.2002.html|title=Save the Minnesota Twins.com - Articles - Ventura pitches Twins plan|website=www.savetheminnesotatwins.com |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} Instead, St. Paul legislators, led by new mayor [[Randy Kelly]], and aided by Hennepin County legislators wanting to keep their constituents off the hook, played hardball, and amended the ballpark bill so that only cities -- not counties -- could become financial partners in a ballpark. They knew that this move would eliminate both Hennepin County and Minneapolis (by virtue of the $10 million cap on any contribution), and leave only St. Paul as a viable partner.{{Cite web|url=http://www.savetheminnesotatwins.com/articles/05.25.2002.html|title=Save the Minnesota Twins.com - Articles - Twins ballpark in St. Paul faces eight obstacles|website=www.savetheminnesotatwins.com |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} The bill passed, and Ventura signed it, but the strategy backfired. The Twins investigated and quickly rejected St. Paul as an implausible place to build.{{Cite web|url=http://www.savetheminnesotatwins.com/articles/07.11.2002.html|title=Save the Minnesota Twins.com - Articles - St. Paul, Twins end stadium talks; no ballot question|website=www.savetheminnesotatwins.com |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} Nothing came of the bill, and it effectively ended any serious talk of the team moving to St. Paul. As 2002 ended, the Twins proclaimed publicly their dissatisfaction with the Rapid Park site. Twins president [[Dave St. Peter]] was quoted as saying that the site was "set off to the side of Downtown, and [has] the garbage incinerator issue." === Spinning wheels and evolving deals (2003-2005) === ==== 2003 ==== With the [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/timecapsule/session?sess=83 2003 Minnesota Legislature] locked in bitter budget issues, the ballpark was never a central focus. No ballpark bill was passed during the session. New governor [[Tim Pawlenty]], who, as a legislator, had been against public spending on stadiums, created the 20-member [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/docs/2004/other/040634/Stadium/www.stadium.state.mn.us/index-2.html Stadium Screening Committee] to "solve Minnesota's stadium conundrum." The committee was notable primarily for focusing equally on facilities for the Vikings and the Twins. They requested proposals from anyone anywhere with an idea for a stadium, and received 26, some more serious than others.{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2004/01/16_khoom_stadiumplans/|title=MPR: Stadium committee awash in ballpark proposals|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} Serious baseball proposals were received from Hennepin County/City of Minneapolis,{{Cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/stories/2003/12/22/daily24.html |title=Minneapolis proposes baseball stadium at downtown site |website=www.bizjournals.com |accessdate=June 10, 2017}} and the City of St. Paul. The Twins, though they did not either send or endorse a proposal, did premiere a new design and scale model for the committee.{{Cite web|url=http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20040106&content_id=624669&vkey=pr_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|title=Twins unveils new ballpark vision|website=Minnesota Twins|language=en|accessdate=April 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422122523/http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20040106&content_id=624669&vkey=pr_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|archive-date=April 22, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Football proposals were received from the cities of Blaine and Eden Prairie. In the end, the recommendations in their [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/docs/2004/other/040634/Stadium/www.stadium.state.mn.us/rec/report_plus.pdf final report] (issued on February 2, 2004) were so general that they added nothing new to the debate, and the committee was dismissed as being for appearances only. Separately, Bruce Lambrecht and Rich Pogin reframed the discussion of their site with a proposal to create "Twinsville" as a neighborhood anchored by the new Twins ballpark.{{Cite news|url=|title=A Downtown Ballpark Village?|last=St. Anthony|first=Neil|date=September 18, 2003|work=Minneapolis Star-Tribune|access-date=}} Concept drawings showed apartment buildings, commercial buildings and townhouses flanking the ballpark to the north and south, all clustered around a newly daylighted [[Bassett Creek (Crystal, Minnesota)|Bassett Creek]] (which runs in a deep culvert beneath the land). In a nod to Pawlenty's football focus, one provocative drawing included a football stadium to the west (on the current HERC site), sharing a retractable roof with the baseball facility. But this concept also hinted at the possibility that the land might have more valuable uses than as a home for the Twins, an idea which would play a significant role later. Nevertheless, their reframing succeeded in jump-starting interest in the project as plans began to form for bringing about action during the forthcoming 2004 legislative session. The year ended with Minneapolis officially authorizing negotiations with Land Partners II (the investment group which owned the Rapid Park site) to gain control of the land.{{Cite news|url=|title=Minneapolis approves Warehouse site for Twins ballpark|last=Olson|first=Rochelle|date=December 30, 2003|work=Minneapolis Star-Tribune|access-date=}} ==== 2004 ==== Early in 2004 the Twins unveiled a new vision of a stadium which could be built on any site with a footprint of at least four square blocks. Two concept drawings, with and without a retractable roof, were accompanied by a scale model (with roof) which was displayed at TwinsFest in January at the Metrodome. The report of Gov. Pawlenty's Stadium Screening Committee set off what the Star-Tribune described as "bitter financing competition between St. Paul and Hennepin County."{{Cite news|url=|title=Ballpark: Fix and advance the bill|last=Board|first=Editorial|date=April 30, 2004|work=Minneapolis Star-Tribune|access-date=}} Though never seriously in the running, St. Paul's efforts effectively sabotaged Hennepin County again. Pawlenty advanced a plan that could build up to three stadiums (Twins, Vikings, and Gophers) albeit with uncertain financing. That uncertainty, combined with dollar amounts now in the billions, and intense partisan bickering over unrelated budget issues, meant that the stadium bill took a back seat and was not passed during the [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/timecapsule/session?sess=83 2004 session]. Behind the scenes in 2004, Hennepin County, led by commissioner [[Mike Opat]], continued negotiations with the Twins, settling on the rough framework for financing which was ultimately used. And the city of Minneapolis, acting on the recommendation of its own advisory committee, worked out an option (assignable to Hennepin County) to purchase the Rapid Park land.{{Cite news|url=|title=$10 reserves site for possible Twins park|last=Sitaramiah|first=Gita|date=February 14, 2004|work=St. Paul Pioneer Press|access-date=}} They agreed to pay $12.95 million plus 5 acres of adjacent land in exchange for the rights to purchase the 8-acre main ballpark site, effectively agreeing to pay $4.3 million per acre. This agreement expired at the end of 2004 when no stadium bill was passed, but it would play a key role in the later condemnation proceedings. ==== 2005 ==== 2005 is remembered as the year that all parties thought a deal could get done, but it never happened. On April 26, 2005, Hennepin County and the Twins announced that they had reached a deal on financing.{{Cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2005/04/25_williamsb_twins/|title=MPR: Pohlad: Contribution to Twins ballpark `fair, substantial'|last=Radio|first=Minnesota Public|website=news.minnesota.publicradio.org|language=en |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} It closely matched what would be the eventual funding solution. In it, the Twins essentially relinquished their desire to put a roof on any new facility, accepting that it was not a financial possibility. Though the ballpark was a subject of sometimes intense discussion in the [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/timecapsule/session?sess=84 2005 Minnesota Legislative session], it fell victim to a political climate which resulted in a lengthy shutdown of Minnesota government due to a budget impasse. No action was taken in either the regular session or the special session which resolved the budget dispute. Until the very end of the year, proponents held out hope that Pawlenty would call a second special session just for the purpose of dealing with the stadium issue, but he did not. === Success (2006) === With the entire Minnesota Legislature up for reelection in 2006, the session began with no expectation that a ballpark bill could pass. All parties were now committed to both the Hennepin County financing plan and the Rapid Park site, meaning all of the building blocks were in place for a deal, but optimism among the stakeholders was almost impossible to find. It took Twins fan and blogger [https://www.lib.umn.edu/about/staff/shane-nackerud Shane Nackerud] to discover that the votes were there. He had long maintained a detailed spreadsheet of legislator statements on the ballpark issue, and was shocked to find, at the beginning of 2006, that the totals ran counter to the conventional wisdom. Both the House and the Senate contained enough "yes" votes to make passage possible. He passed his information to Lambrecht and Pogin, who made sure his spreadsheet got the widest possible distribution. This spurred all parties to push hard for the passage of a bill in the [https://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/timecapsule/session?sess=84 2006 session]. On April 18, 2006 Hennepin County formally approved a plan to contribute $392 million to a Twins ballpark on the Rapid Park site. The funds would be raised through a county-wide 0.15% sales tax which would also raise funds to support the [[Hennepin County Library|Hennepin County Libraries]] and youth sports activities within the county.{{Cite news|url=https://www.tcdailyplanet.net/hennepin-county-falls-back-sales-tax-base-support-libraries-0/|title=“Ballpark Mondays” will open some Minneapolis libraries|work=Twin Cities Daily Planet|accessdate=April 21, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The plan was exempted from any public referendum.{{Cite web|url=http://www.baseball-fever.com/showthread.php?41956-Hennepin-board-OKs-Twins-stadium-plan|title=Hennepin board OKs Twins stadium plan|website=www.baseball-fever.com|language=en |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} Final deliberations in the legislature centered on whether a referendum either was or should be required for any portion of the financing. All sides recognized that such a requirement would kill the project, and thus it became a proxy for deciding whether a ballpark should be built at all. On May 20, 2006 the Minnesota Legislature approved a bill{{Cite web|url=https://www.revisor.mn.gov/bills/bill.php?b=House&f=HF2480&ssn=0&y=2005|title=HF 2480 Status in the House for the 84th Legislature (2005 - 2006)|website=www.revisor.mn.gov|language=en |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} authorizing a new Twins ballpark on the Rapid Park site at an initial budgeted cost of $522 million. The cost was to be split between the Minnesota Twins (25%) and Hennepin County (75%). The Twins agreed to a total contribution of $130 million. A public referendum was not required.{{Cite web|url=https://votesmart.org/bill/865/3132/3749/thomas-bakk-voted-yea-passage-hf-2480-baseball-stadium-financing-construction-and-operation#.WPo3UW_yvmg|title=The Voter's Self Defense System|website=Vote Smart|language=en-US |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} On May 26, 2006, Governor Tim Pawlenty signed the legislation in front of a large crowd at the Metrodome before the start of a Twins game.{{Cite web|url=http://m.twins.mlb.com/news/article/1473342/|title=Gov. Pawlenty signs new ballpark bill|website=Minnesota Twins|language=en-US|accessdate=April 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908191343/http://m.twins.mlb.com/news/article/1473342|archive-date=September 8, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Several procedural votes were still necessary by the Hennepin County Board, any of which had the potential to derail the project. The final of these was held on August 29, 2006, officially authorizing the imposition of the sales tax, effective January 1, 2007.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2006/08/29/stadiumtaxvote|title=Twins win Hennepin County stadium sales tax|last=Williams|first=Brandt |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} With the success of this vote, all legislative pieces were in place to formally authorize the ballpark, though acquisition of the Rapid Park land remained. Construction of Target Field began on May 21, 2007. === Land Dispute (2007) === As work began on the ballpark, a final major snag threatened to derail the entire project for almost a year. The bill authorizing the financing of Target Field specified a cap of $90 million for onsite infrastructure costs, which included land acquisition. Surprisingly, even though they were now authorized, Hennepin County did not take any action to acquire the land until very late in 2006. Eventually, it was revealed that the county had budgeted $13.5 million for the land, or about $1.7 million per acre for 8 acres,{{Cite web|url=http://www.pressreader.com/usa/star-tribune/20070106/281535106509221|title=PressReader.com - Connecting People Through News|website=www.pressreader.com |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} mistakenly assuming they could acquire it for roughly the dollar amount of the 2004 option agreement between the city of Minneapolis and Land Partners II (the investment group which owned Rapid Park). The dollar amount on that deal had been $12.9 million, though the deal had also included 5 acres of adjacent land. Effectively, it would have paid for only three acres of the 8-acre site that Hennepin County now needed to acquire, at a proposed price of $4.3 million per acre. In addition to those numbers being far apart, much had changed since the 2004 deal expired. The Hiawatha Light Rail (later Blue Line) had opened and become a huge success. Funding for the Northstar commuter rail line had been approved. As anticipated, these two lines would eventually converge on the northwest corner of the Rapid Park Site, now the likely location for a future [[Target Field (Metro Transit station)|multi-modal transportation hub]]. The site itself had been rezoned in 2005, allowing its development into high end commercial and residential space. Land Partners II had entered into a development agreement with [[Hines Interests Limited Partnership|Hines Corporation]] for this purpose, as a backup in the event that the land was not chosen as home for the Twins.{{Cite web|url=http://www.citypages.com/news/stealing-home-6689395|title=Stealing Home {{!}} City Pages|last=Robson|first=Britt|website=City Pages |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} Given the scarcity of land available in downtown Minneapolis, the land owners had multiple reasons to believe that the land’s value had, in fact, increased substantially since 2004, with or without a ballpark. Still, Lambrecht and Pogin, now acting as spokesmen for Land Partners II and Hines, had long been on record as “willing sellers” of the land for a ballpark, stipulating only that their investment group would expect “fair market value.”{{Cite web|url=http://emdo.blogspot.com/2007/01/stadium-squeeze-not-by-us-minneapolis.html|title=Eminent Domain Watch: Stadium 'squeeze'? Not by us: Minneapolis MN Star-Tribune, 1/6/07|last=Alan|date=January 7, 2007 |website=Eminent Domain Watch |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} Eventually, they admitted that they fully expected the transaction to take place in [[eminent domain]] ([http://www.wtplaw.com/documents/2011/04/basics-of-condemnation condemnation]) proceedings, but accepted that inevitability because it would likely result in a fair purchase price, which they had reason to believe would be at least as much as the per-acre amount of the 2004 deal, or $4.3 million per acre (approximately $34 million for the entire 8-acre site), and perhaps significantly more due to market changes.{{Cite web|url=http://www.citypages.com/news/the-new-twins-park-a-big-roadblock-at-home-plate-6688907|title=The New Twins Park: A Big Roadblock at Home Plate {{!}} City Pages|last=Jr.|first=G.R. Anderson|website=City Pages |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} Hennepin County claimed that accepting the price set by an eminent domain judge was not an option for them, due to the infrastructure cap. Any additional money needed for the land would have to come out of some other piece of infrastructure. If the price set by a judge came in over their budget, they would have no funds to pay, and the project could collapse. But eminent domain did offer them the advantage of getting started on construction while working out the details of the land price later. On September 19, 2006, Hennepin County officially authorized acquisition of the land, including doing so under eminent domain proceedings, if necessary. In late October the initial county appraisal of the land came in at the same $13.5 million that had been budgeted. Eminent domain proceedings were then initiated on November 1, 2006 as a precaution in case no agreement on land value could be reached by the time construction needed to start. The county set March 1, 2007 as the target date for finalizing acquisition of the Rapid Park site. There had still been no negotiations between the county and the land owners. After months passed without an agreement, a harsh war of words erupted in the media in February 2007. The Twins angrily cancelled a planned unveiling of the ballpark design scheduled for February 15, declaring that the entire project was in jeopardy.{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/02/11/land-flap-prompts-twins-to-keep-stadium-design-under-wraps/|title=Land flap prompts Twins to keep stadium design under wraps – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} Jerry Bell of the Twins and Mike Opat of Hennepin County gave multiple interviews{{Cite web|url=http://www.mnvideovault.org/mvvPlayer/customPlaylist2.php?id=7626&select_index=2&popup=yes#2|title=tpt OnDemand Video: Almanac {{!}} New Stadium Woes|website=www.mnvideovault.org |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} in which they described the land owners as being “unwilling sellers,”{{Cite news|url=|title=A Great Divide|last=Kaszuba|first=Mike|date=February 14, 2007|work=Minneapolis Star-Tribune|access-date=}} “greedy,”{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/02/19/pitch-in-twins/|title=Pitch in, Twins – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} “lawyered-up,”{{Cite news|url=|title=News Report|last=KARE-11|first=|date=February 11, 2007|work=KARE-11 News|access-date=}} painted them as “greedy landowners in black hats,”{{Cite web|url=http://www.mnvideovault.org/mvvPlayer/customPlaylist2.php?id=7649&select_index=4&popup=yes#4|title=tpt OnDemand Video: Almanac {{!}} The New Twins Stadium|website=www.mnvideovault.org |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} and as not negotiating in good faith.{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/02/09/hennepin-county-land-deal-holding-up-new-twins-ballpark/|title=Hennepin County / Land deal holding up new Twins ballpark – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} Lambrecht and Pogin continued to insist that they had an obligation to their investors to secure nothing more than “fair market value” for the land.{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/02/12/no-peek-at-stadium-plan-just-yet/|title=No peek at stadium plan just yet – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} They repeatedly said that they would accept whatever valuation was determined in eminent domain proceedings,{{Cite news|url=http://lacrossetribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mn/site-dispute-puts-twins-stadium-in-unclear-situation/article_7d36788a-eb57-5fea-b334-36c7cc93575a.html|title=Site dispute puts Twins stadium in unclear situation|work=La Crosse Tribune |accessdate=April 22, 2017|language=en}} while media reports would later reveal their internal valuation (required by eminent domain laws) to be $65 million. In early April 2007 Hennepin County received assurances that the Twins would provide additional funds, if necessary, to cover cost overruns on infrastructure, including the land acquisition.{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/04/09/hennepin-county-reaches-deal-on-twins-stadium-land/|title=Hennepin County reaches deal on Twins stadium land – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} This allowed the initiation of [http://www.wtplaw.com/documents/2011/04/basics-of-condemnation “quick take”] proceedings, and the county gained control of the site effective May 1, 2007,{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/05/01/county-takes-title-of-land-puts-twins-ballpark-closer-to-reality/|title=County takes title of land, puts Twins ballpark closer to reality – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} with a final sale price to be determined later. This effectively mitigated the problem of the infrastructure cap and allowed the unveiling of the ballpark design on April 12, and construction to begin on May 21, 2007.{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/05/15/minneapolis-clearing-of-ballpark-site-begins-monday/|title=Minneapolis / Clearing of ballpark site begins Monday – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} Despite the beginning of construction, the land stalemate dragged on for months, as did the harsh rhetoric in the media. Some members of the media and public placed blame on Hennepin County for not securing the land before getting authorization to build the ballpark, while others laid the blame on the sellers for allegedly increasing their price once the legislation passed.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2007/07/05/landvaluefight|title=Hennepin County, land owners remain far apart on value of ballpark site|last=Williams|first=Brandt |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} On August 19, 2007, a three-member condemnation panel set the value of the land at $23.8 million by a vote of 2 to 1.{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/08/19/panel-twins-ballpark-site-worth-23-8m/|title=Panel: Twins ballpark site worth $23.8M – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} The next day, a separate opinion valuing the land at $33.2 million was filed by the dissenting judge. The landowners immediately announced that they would appeal the condemnation ruling,{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/08/23/land-price-ruling-for-twins-stadium-site-to-be-appealed/|title=Land price ruling for Twins stadium site to be appealed – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} and a court date was set for November. Ten days later, on August 30, 2007, the ceremonial groundbreaking took place,{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/08/30/after-all-the-nastiness-infield-grass-and-blue-sky/|title=After all the nastiness, infield grass and blue sky – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} despite the ongoing land dispute (the event had been scheduled for August 2,{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/06/18/twins-groundbreaking-for-new-stadium-aug-2/|title=Twins: Groundbreaking for new stadium Aug. 2 – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} but was postponed in the aftermath of the [[I-35W Mississippi River bridge|I-35W bridge collapse]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/08/09/twins-shift-new-ballpark-groundbreaking-back-to-aug-30/|title=Twins shift new ballpark groundbreaking back to Aug. 30 – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}}). Eventually, after exchanging divergent values for several weeks, both parties agreed to mediation,{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/09/12/county-landowners-agree-to-mediation-over-stadium-site-dispute/|title=County, landowners agree to mediation over stadium site dispute – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} and with the November court date fast approaching, the final agreement was reached on October 12, 2007,{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2007/10/14/hennepin-county-to-pay-28m-for-twins-ballpark-land-pohlad-to-pay-15m-more/|title=Hennepin County to pay $28M for Twins ballpark land; Pohlad to pay $15M more – Twin Cities |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} with a negotiated price of $29 million.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2007/10/15/stadiumlanddeal|title=Two sides agree on stadium land sale, but don't sound happy|last=Williams|first=Brandt |accessdate=April 22, 2017}} To make the deal possible, the Twins had agreed to make up the $15 million difference between that price and what Hennepin County had originally budgeted. In exchange, they received the right to develop several acres near the ballpark. Land Partners II received property and air rights over Dock Street, which was to be created for access to the ballpark from the north. With the establishment of the land value, the final potential obstacle to the completion of Target Field was resolved. === Naming === On September 15, 2008, the Twins and Minneapolis-based [[Target Corporation]] announced that the ballpark would be named Target Field. Financial terms of the [[naming rights]] agreement were not disclosed.{{cite press release |title=Minnesota Twins and Target Announce New Partnership|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20080915&content_id=3479747&vkey=pr_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=September 15, 2008|accessdate=September 15, 2008}} The company's investment also funded a pedestrian bridge from the ballpark to downtown, Target Plaza, more seating, canopies and public art.{{cite news |title=New Ballpark Will Be Named 'Target Field'|first=Michelle|last=Bruch|url=http://www.downtownjournal.com/index.php?&story=12363&page=65&category=86|work=Downtown Journal|publisher=Minnesota Premier Publications|date=September 15, 2008|accessdate=September 15, 2008}} ===Design=== [[File:Targetfield2.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Exterior of Target Field, including a view of the commuter platform at [[Target Field (Metro Transit station)|Target Field station]].]]Designed by [[Populous (company)|Populous]] with Bruce Miller as principal lead, Target Field is a modern take on other Populous-designed stadiums such as [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards]] in Baltimore, [[PNC Park]] in Pittsburgh, and [[AT&T Park]] in San Francisco.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.citypages.com/sports/2008/06/interview_with.php|title=Interview with Bruce Miller, Principal Architect for the Twins Ballpark|last=Spicer|first=Judd|date=June 12, 2008|publisher=City Pages|accessdate=June 12, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080614042052/http://blogs.citypages.com/sports/2008/06/interview_with.php|archivedate=June 14, 2008|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ballparkdigest.com/news/2007/twins_ballpark.html|title=Twins ballpark plans Unveiled|last=Wright|first=Dave|date=April 12, 2007|work=Ballpark Digest|accessdate=April 12, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071028030112/http://www.ballparkdigest.com/news/2007/twins_ballpark.html|archivedate=October 28, 2007|df=mdy-all}}[[File:Target Field and skyline 2014-05-14.jpg|250px|thumb|right|View of downtown Minneapolis from Target Field, May 14, 2014]] The architects tried to avoid creating a replica of the old-style brick [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards|Camden Yards]] or modern urban design of the new [[Nationals Park]] (both also designed by Populous).{{cite news|title=Twins Ballpark: Above Us ... Only Sky|first=Mike|last=Kaszuba|url=http://www.startribune.com/509/story/1115358.html|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=April 12, 2007|accessdate=April 12, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416025546/http://www.startribune.com/509/story/1115358.html|archivedate=April 16, 2007|df=mdy-all}} Instead, the design for the stadium employs local limestone, heated viewing areas and a heated field.{{cite web|title=Renderings for Twins Park Shown|first=John|last=Gilbert|url=http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20070412&content_id=1895070&vkey=ballpark_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=April 12, 2007|accessdate=April 12, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416132921/http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20070412&content_id=1895070&vkey=ballpark_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|archive-date=April 16, 2007|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The stadium does not have a roof, but there is a canopy above the top deck. The stadium is integrated with the intermodal [[Target Field (Metro Transit station)|Target Field station]] which connects the [[Blue Line (Minnesota)|METRO Blue]] and [[Green Line (Minnesota)|Green Line]] [[light rail]] service with the Minneapolis terminus of the [[Northstar Line|Northstar]] [[commuter rail]] line leading from the northwest. [[Walter P Moore]] served as the structural engineer for the stadium and canopy. The stadium does not have a [[retractable roof]], though one was considered initially. Such a roof was cited to add $100 million to the total budget and none of the parties (Twins, [[Hennepin County]] or [[Minnesota Legislature]]) were willing to pay for that cost.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} Much like other northern cities with outdoor professional baseball (i.e. Chicago, Detroit, Boston, Cleveland, New York), the [[Climate of the Twin Cities|weather in Minneapolis]] during a 162-game baseball season and playoffs can vary from early-spring snow to rain and hot, humid weather. The Metrodome was climate-controlled, and thus, protected the baseball schedule during the entire time that it had been the venue for the Minnesota Twins. However, many Twins fans and baseball purists argue that this same sterile, climate-controlled environment creates a less-than-desirable atmosphere for watching baseball. The architect also tested the feasibility of heated seats.{{cite web|title=Twins Stadium Model Reveals Design Tweaks|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://wcco.com/sports/twins.stadium.model.2.462078.html|work=[[WCCO-TV|WCCO]]|location=Minneapolis|date=October 30, 2007|accessdate=October 30, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031194813/http://wcco.com/sports/twins.stadium.model.2.462078.html|archivedate=October 31, 2007|df=mdy-all}} The site is about the same size as that of [[Fenway Park]], and the ballpark holds roughly the same number of seats. The site is bounded by 3rd Avenue (southeast, right field, across from Target Center); 5th Street North (northeast, left field); 7th Street North (southwest, first base); Hennepin Environmental Recovery Center [garbage [[incinerator]]] and 6th Avenue North (northwest, third base). 3rd Avenue is a westbound one-way street which dips down under the right field seats and serves as a ramp to I-394 westbound. A separate, small westbound segment of 3rd Avenue, connecting 7th Street North with Glenwood Avenue, was renamed "Twins Way". The ballpark's street address, "1 Twins Way", is at the "foot" of the renamed street. ===Construction=== [[Image:051907-009-TwinsBallparkSite.jpg|250px|thumb|The site of Target Field, two days before construction commenced on May 21, 2007. The location is bordered by 7th St. N (overpass on left), the Hennepin Energy Recovery Center, 5th St. N (overpass on the right side), and the 394 exits and downtown parking ramp (foreground). The tall red building is the Ford Centre.]] [[Image:2008-0511-TwinsBallparkSite-001.jpg|250px|thumb|right|The same site as above, approximately one year later (357 days)]] [[File:2009-0524-MN-TargetField03.jpg|250px|thumb|right|The same site as above, 378 days after the previous photo and approximately two years (733 days) since construction commenced]] Mortenson Construction of Minneapolis built the stadium. [http://www.metromech.com/ Metropolitan Mechanical Contractors] completed the mechanical contracting. [http://www.DannysConstruction.com/ Danny's Construction Company] erected the structural steel. Subcontractors involved in the concrete work include CECO Concrete Construction, Gephart Electric, E&J Rebar, Ambassador Steel Corporation, [[Amsysco Inc.]], and Nordic Construction/Cemstone.{{cite web|title=Another Twins Ballpark Milestone Reached on Wednesday|url=http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20080123&content_id=2353768&vkey=ballpark_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=January 23, 2008|accessdate=January 23, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316012914/http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20080123&content_id=2353768&vkey=ballpark_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|archive-date=March 16, 2008|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The first concrete slab was poured on December 17, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://twinsballpark.mlblogs.com/archives/2007/12/|title=Another Ballpark Milestone: First Concrete Slab Pour|last=St. Peter|first=Dave|date=December 17, 2007|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|accessdate=August 27, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920022025/http://twinsballpark.mlblogs.com/archives/2007/12/|archivedate=September 20, 2008|df=mdy-all}} The concrete portion of construction was completed in November 2008 with a roof deck pour for the Twins administration building. In March 2009 Tekna Kleen (commercial cleaning company), started doing the finishing cleaning touches to Target Field.{{cite web |title=Twins Stadium Project Ahead of Schedule|first=Brian|last=Johnson|url=http://www.finance-commerce.com/article.cfm/2008/11/22/Twins-stadium-project-ahead-of-schedule|work=Finance and Commerce|date=November 22, 2008|accessdate=November 22, 2008}} In late August, 2009, the playing field was installed.{{cite web |title=Challenges Remain to Get Field Ready|first=Kelly|last=Thesier|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090826&content_id=6628122&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=August 26, 2009|accessdate=August 26, 2009}} The Twins received the certificate of occupancy from Mortenson Construction on December 22, 2009. The Twins staff moved in on January 4, 2010.[http://www.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20100104&content_id=7872742&vkey=news_min&fext=.jsp Twins handed keys to Target Field]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} [[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]] ===LEED Certification=== Target Field was initially awarded [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] Silver Certification by the U.S. Green Building Council, the second LEED-certified professional sports stadium in the United States, after [[AT&T Park]]. It is one of 3 baseball stadiums with LEED certification (the other being [[Nationals Park]]).{{cite web|first=Heather|last=Benjamin|title=LEED Link: Find a LEED stadium near you|url=https://www.usgbc.org/articles/leed-link-find-leed-stadium-near-you|publisher=[[U.S. Green Building Council]]|date=May 23, 2017|accessdate=March 6, 2018}} In 2017, Target Field was recertified LEED Gold, the first sports site in the nation to be so designated.{{cite news|first=Rochelle|last=Olson|title=Target Field honored as greenest ballpark in America|url=http://www.startribune.com/target-field-honored-as-greenest-ballpark-in-america/420152943/|publisher=[[StarTribune Media, LLC|Star Tribune]]|date=April 23, 2017|accessdate=March 6, 2018}} ===Upgrades=== [[File:New 2nd scoreboard.jpg|200px|thumb|right|The right field scoreboard, photo taken March 2011.]] On February 12, 2008, the Twins announced $22.4 million in upgrades to the original design, and increased the Twins ownership stake in the ballpark to $167.4 million, bringing the total ballpark cost to $412 million.Jim Molony, {{cite web|title=Twins Kick in Extra Funds for Ballpark|first=Jim|last=Molony|url=http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20080212&content_id=2371679&vkey=ballpark_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=February 14, 2008|accessdate=February 14, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316012919/http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20080212&content_id=2371679&vkey=ballpark_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|archive-date=March 16, 2008|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |title=Ballpark Enhancements Help Ensure Superior Fan Experience|first=Dave|last=St. Peter|url=http://twinsballpark.mlblogs.com/twinsballpark/2008/02/ballpark_enhanc.html|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=February 14, 2008|accessdate=February 14, 2008}} The upgrades were mainly based around increasing fan experience and comfort. The upgrades included an enlarged canopy [[soffit]] (the largest in baseball), protecting fans further from the elements, in light of the stadium not having a roof. The Twins also upgraded the scoreboard – the fourth-largest in Major League Baseball – from standard definition to a high definition display from [[Daktronics]] measuring {{convert|101|ft|m}} long and {{convert|57|ft|m}} high.{{cite news|title=Twins Scoreboard: Larger Than Life, and Twice As Gizmo-y|first=Paul|last=Walsh|url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/twins/32897324.html?elr=KArksi8cyaiUqCP:iUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aULPQL7PQLanchO7DiU|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=October 23, 2008|accessdate=October 23, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026150129/http://www.startribune.com/sports/twins/32897324.html?elr=KArksi8cyaiUqCP:iUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aULPQL7PQLanchO7DiU|archive-date=October 26, 2008|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite press release |title=Minnesota Twins Open Target Field with Integrated Daktronics Super System|url=http://www.daktronics.com/Company/NewsReleases/Pages/MinnesotaTwinsTargetField.aspx|publisher=[[Daktronics]]|date=April 13, 2010}} Other upgrades included warming shelters, changing {{convert|100000|sqft|m2}} of the exterior surface to [[Kasota limestone|Kasota stone]], and increasing the number of restrooms and concession areas. The park features a modernized version of the original "Minnie and Paul Shaking Hands" logo used on the team's original uniforms from 1961 until 1986 (the logo has also been on the home uniforms since 2001). When a Twins player hits a home run, the Minnie and Paul sign lights up with strobe lights surrounding the Minnesota state outline and Minnie and Paul shake hands, akin to the Liberty Bell used at [[Citizens Bank Park]] in Philadelphia. The original flagpole from [[Metropolitan Stadium]] – completely restored – is located on the right field plaza. The flagpole was located at the [[American Legion]] post in [[Richfield, Minnesota|Richfield]] after Metropolitan Stadium's closing, and was donated back to the Twins by the Legion as a gesture of goodwill. On November 10, 2010, the Twins announced a number of upgrades to Target Field, all of which were completed in time for the 2011 season. Highlights among the upgrades included a scoreboard in right-center field and the "Twins Tower" (a {{convert|100|ft|m|adj=on}} tall illuminated tower), next to the new scoreboard. Other changes include free [[Wi-Fi]] service for fans, expanded concession stand menus, and the addition of more radiant heaters and artwork around the ballpark. In total, the changes were expected to cost the Twins $4–6 million.{{cite news |title=Target Field Set for Upgrades|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=5789289|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=November 10, 2010|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} Additionally, the 14 black spruce trees located in the [[batter's eye]] were removed, following hitters' complaints that the trees interfered with the ability to see pitches as they would sometimes sway in the wind.{{cite news |title=Twins Clear-Cut Target Field|url=http://ballparkdigest.com/201103013616/major-league-baseball/news/twins-clear-cut-target-field|work=Ballpark Digest|date=March 1, 2010|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} The batter's eye wall itself was covered in a black material designed to reduce glare.{{cite web |title=New Batter's Eye Draws Positive Reviews|first1=Rhett|last1=Bollinger|first2=Jordan|last2=Schelling|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/print.jsp?ymd=20110409&content_id=17555492¬ebook_id=17567806&vkey=notebook_min|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=April 9, 2011|accessdate=April 9, 2011}} [[File:Target Field 1.jpg|700px|thumb|center|Panorama of Target Field, taken from the concourse inside Gate 29.]] ==Non-baseball events== ===Concerts=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !
