[[Chris Lane]] || [[Smooth Tour]] || 37,592 / 37,592 || $3,109,656 || |- | June 30, 2018 || [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]|| [[Jimmy Buffett]] || An Evening with the Eagles 2018 || 42,185 / 42,185 || {{tba}} || {{cite news|url=http://m.twins.mlb.com/news/article/262267796/target-field-to-host-eagles-jimmy-buffett/|title=Eagles, Jimmy Buffett to play at Target Field|publisher=MLB.com}} |- | July 21, 2018 ||[[Luke Bryan]] || [[Sam Hunt]]
[[Jon Pardi]]
[[Morgan Wallen]] || [[What Makes You Country Tour]] || 36,078 / 36,385 || $2,921,581 || |- | July 27, 2018 || [[Def Leppard]]
[[Journey (band)|Journey]] || [[Cheap Trick]] || [[Def Leppard & Journey 2018 Tour]] || 37,960 / 37,960 || $3,333,263 || |- | August 10, 2018 || [[Zac Brown Band]] || [[OneRepublic]] || [[Down the Rabbit Hole Live]] || {{tba}} || {{tba}} || |} Starting in 2013, Target Field has hosted every summer the Skyline Music Festival, named so because its seating, with only the seats around third base in an [[Amphitheatre]]-like manner, allows for extensive views of the Minneapolis skyline.[http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/music/261812231.html Melissa Etheridge to headline at Target Field for Skyline Music Festival] The inaugural edition was held on July 26, 2013, featuring three of four bands in a package tour – [[Soul Asylum]], [[Matthew Sweet]] and [[Big Head Todd and the Monsters]], each of whom played one of their past albums in their entirety – along with Minnesota band [[Gear Daddies]]. The 6,752 tickets allowed by the section were sold out.[http://www.twincities.com/music/ci_23742748/review-twins-hit-home-run-skyline-music-festival ] The following edition was extended to two nights. August 8 featured an [[indie rock]] night sponsored by [[KCMP]], featuring [[Andrew Bird]], [[The New Pornographers]], [[Thao and the Get Down Stay Down]], [[S. Carey]] and [[Dosh (musician)|Dosh]].[http://www.thecurrent.org/events/2014/08/08/742/skyline-music-festival-andrew-bird-new-pornographers-thao--the-get-down-stay-down-s-carey--dosh/ Skyline Music Festival: Andrew Bird, New Pornographers, Thao & the Get Down Stay Down, S. Carey & Dosh] The following night was headlined by [[Melissa Etheridge]], accompanied by the returning Gear Daddies, along with [[The Honeydogs]], [[O.A.R. (band)|O.A.R.]] and [[The Rembrandts]].[http://www.twincities.com/localnews/ci_26309515/skyline-music-festival-review-minnesota-bands-set-stage] Attendance was 2,500 for the first night and 5,500 for the second.[http://www.twincities.com/music/ci_26335646/ross-raihalas-column-target-field-concerts-hit] ==Features== {{prose|section|date=December 2017}} ===The stadium=== *The popular left-field [[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]] roof deck features mostly standing room and the only bonfire in the Majors. *The bullpens are "double-decker" style in left-center field. The Twins' pen is farthest from the field, with the opposing team's pen below it, closest to the field. *The batter's eye featured 14 young [[Picea mariana|black spruce]] trees (each about 6 feet high) the first year. After criticism from Twins and opposing players concerning the shadows that they cast, the trees were removed prior to the second year. Some were auctioned to fans and ticket holders while the rest were donated to [[List of Minnesota state parks|Minnesota state parks]]. *[[Kasota limestone]] is used in much of the stadium and is from [[Kasota, Minnesota|Kasota]], near [[Mankato, Minnesota|Mankato]]. *The admission gates are numbered according to former Twins legends and roughly located near to the positions that they played; **Left field gate is #6 honoring [[Tony Oliva]] (with his bronze statue nearby) **Centerfield gate is #3 for [[Harmon Killebrew]] **Target Plaza gate (in right field) is #34 in tribute to [[Kirby Puckett]] **Right field gate is #29 in tribute to [[Rod Carew]] **Home plate gate is #14 in honor of [[Kent Hrbek]] (featuring his bronze statue) ===Target Plaza=== Target Plaza is the gathering area behind the right field gate (Gate 34). On the wall of the adjacent parking garage facing the ballpark is a wind veil that makes waves as the wind blows. At night, color-changing lights add to the effect. Near the wind veil there are 9 topiary frames each {{convert|40|ft|m}} high shaped like baseball bats with hops growing on them. They are lit up every night with the same color changing scheme as the veil, however, during games they are lit up red, in sequential order, to denote the current inning.[http://www.startribune.com/sports/twins/90324237.html Visuals big part of trip to Target Field] ''[[Star Tribune]]'' In this plaza are statues of former players [[Kirby Puckett]], [[Rod Carew]], [[Kent Hrbek]] and [[Harmon Killebrew]], as well as former owners [[Calvin Griffith]], [[Carl Pohlad]] and his wife, Eloise Pohlad and Twins mascot TC Bear.{{cite news |title=Carew Supports Griffith Statue Being Placed Near His Target Field Gate|first=Paul|last=Walsh|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/101657538.html|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis|date=August 27, 2010|accessdate=August 27, 2010}} A large "Golden Glove" sits in the plaza in recognition of all Twins players to win the Gold Glove Award. The statue can be sat on and is a popular photo attraction. It is located exactly {{convert|520|ft|m}} from home plate, the distance of Harmon Killebrew's longest home run at Met Stadium (although his was hit into the left field upper deck). There is also a monument that shows all the venues that Minnesota-based baseball teams played in. On the rails of the pedestrian skybridge are pennants that contain the rosters of all the Twins teams, and pennants of players, coaches, front office people, and other contributors who have been elected to the Twins Hall of Fame. ===The field=== The main flagpoles are in right field near the Plaza. The largest pole, which flies the Stars and Stripes, is the original pole used at [[Metropolitan Stadium]]. It was relocated to the Richfield Legion Post 435 after the Met was demolished, and, after being cut in half and refurbished, was re-installed for baseball at Target Field. The first flags--both US and POW/MIA--donated by Post 435 were raised at the first Twins exhibition game by veteran and flagpole historian B.W. McEvers of Bloomington. On September 6, [[Jim Thome]] hit a solo home run against the [[Kansas City Royals]] that hit the flag pole. The championship banners fly on small flagpoles located on the upper rim of the stadium beyond left field. Each pole recognizes each division, league, and world championship since the team's arrival in {{mlby|1961}}. On the stadium's upper rim in right-center field are small flagpoles that fly the flag for all the teams (including the Twins) in the division. The order that the flags fly are determined by the divisional standings. Home plate is the same one used at the Metrodome. After the Twins' final dome game (Game 3 of the [[2009 American League Division Series|2009 ALDS]]), the plate was dug up and later installed at Target Field. In addition, several handfuls of dirt were taken from the sliding pit and pitcher's mound areas from the Metrodome and scattered near their counterparts at Target Field. ===Twins bars and restaurants=== At Target Field, there are three prominent bars and restaurants: *The Town Ball Tavern is located on the upper concourse by the left field corner, and is famous for serving the [[Jucy Lucy]] burger. The wood flooring is the same used on the basketball court at the [[Minneapolis Armory]] during the NBA [[Minneapolis Lakers]] stay, before leaving for Los Angeles. *Hrbek's is located on the main concourse behind home plate, and is named after former Twins [[first baseman]] [[Kent Hrbek]]. *There are two bars located on the upper concourse behind home plate, collectively called the Two Gingers Pubs. In one of these bars, fans can watch the Target Field organist, Sue Nelson, perform during games. Out of these three bars and restaurants, the Two Gingers Pub (formerly known as the Twins Pub) is the only one that does not serve food, however it is the only one in which the field is visible from inside. Concessions throughout also include several Minnesota favorites like walleye, wild rice soup, Kramarczuk's sausages, as well as a "State Fair Foods" stand where many items are served "on a stick", such as the J.D. Hoyt's pork chop. In 2018, [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] declared Target Field number one on its annual list of [[vegan]]-friendly ballparks, thanks to the availability of foods like tofu vindaloo, vegan Sriracha Brats and Italian Sausages, [[Daiya]] cheese pizza, and Field Roast burgers and dogs.Kevin Reichard, "Target Field Leads List of Vegan-Friendly Ballparks," [https://ballparkdigest.com/2018/06/04/target-field-leads-list-of-vegan-friendly-ballparks/ BallparkDigest.com], 4 June 2018. ===Minnie and Paul logo=== [[File:Minnie and Paul.jpg|thumb|right|300px.|Minnie and Paul, representing the Twin Cities, is the logo for the Minnesota Twins.]] A large version of the Twins' original "Minnie and Paul" logo (designed by local artist, Ray Barton {{cite web |title=Ray Barton obituary|url=http://www.harrisfam.org/rootspersona-tree-2/ray-alphonzo-barton/|work=Harris family genealogy site|accessdate=January 16, 2016}}) stands in center field. It shows two players wearing the uniforms of the two minor-league teams that played in the Twin Cities before the Twins' arrival, the [[Minneapolis Millers]] and [[St. Paul Saints (1901–60)|St. Paul Saints]], shaking hands across the [[Mississippi River]]. During various points in the game, the strobe lights surrounding the logo flash. This sign was a concept designed and illustrated by RipBang Studios but built by others. When the Twins score a run by any means other than a home run, the strobe lights trace the border from the bottom-left corner for each Twins player that crosses home plate, symbolizing that a Twins player rounded the bases. For each strikeout, the corners of the sign flash to portray the strike zone. The strobe lights will flash at the end of the top of an inning if the Twins do not surrender a run during the inning. After a Twins home run, the strobe lights flash, Minnie and Paul shake hands, and the Mississippi River flows. After a Twins victory, the "T" and "s" in "Twins" will blink to show the message "Twins win" in addition to the animation shown following a Twins home run. ==METRO and commuter rail connections== The stadium is well-connected to the city's transit network, being immediately adjacent to the "A" and "B" [[parking ramp]]s of the large ABC Ramps complex at the end of [[Interstate 394]], which include two major transit bus terminals and link to the rest of downtown Minneapolis via [[skyway]]. Over 8,000 people typically arrive to each game via the [[Blue Line (Minnesota)|METRO Blue Line]] and [[Green Line (Minnesota)|METRO Green Line]], both of which terminate at [[Target Field (Metro Transit station)|Target Field Station]], just 10 yards from the park's Gate 6. For fans arriving from the northwest suburbs, the [[Northstar Line]] commuter rail terminates in downtown Minneapolis with a station underneath the ballpark. ==Park firsts== The first "soft event" at Target Field was an open house held for season ticket holders on March 20 and 21, 2010.[[File:First Pitch at Target Field.jpg|thumb|First Pitch at Target Field, thrown by Jordan, Minnesota native T.J. Oakes of the University of Minnesota Golden Gophers on March 27, 2010.]] The first baseball game at the new ballpark took place on March 27, 2010, with a [[college baseball]] game between the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers|University of Minnesota]] and [[Louisiana Tech Bulldogs baseball|Louisiana Tech]] attended by 37,757 fans. The Twins played two preseason games against the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] on April 2 and 3, while the stadium's inaugural regular season game was on April 12, {{mlby|2010}} against the [[Boston Red Sox|Red Sox]].{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20100327&content_id=8968842&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=Target Field Opens with College Game|last=Theiser|first=Kelly|date=March 27, 2010|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|accessdate=March 27, 2010}} ===Opening day (April 12, 2010)=== {| class="wikitable" align=center style="margin-left:15px; text-align:center; background:#ffffff;" |- | style="{{Baseball primary style|Minnesota Twins}};|'''Statistic''' | style="{{Baseball primary style|Minnesota Twins}};|'''Player(s)/Team''' |- ! style="{{Baseball primary style|Minnesota Twins}};|'''''Characteristic''''' ! style="{{Baseball primary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Target Field ! style="{{Baseball primary style|Minnesota Twins}};|H.H.H. Metrodome |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Seats | 38,649* || 46,564** |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Lower Deck Seats | 19,000 || 21,621 |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Private Suites | 54 || 115*** |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Group Party Suites | 12 || 1 |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Club Level Seats | 7,000 || — |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Upper Deck Seats | 13,468 || 28,779 |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Disabled Seating | 820 || 190 |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Lower/Club Seats
between 1st and 3rd Base | about 12,037 || 6,679 |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Outfield Seats | about 6,748 || 18,594 |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Seats with Obstructed Views | < 200 || 1,392 |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Main Concourse | {{convert|40|ft|m}},
open to field || {{convert|22|ft|m}},
closed to field |- ! style="{{Baseball secondary style|Minnesota Twins}};|Total Restrooms | 34 || 16 |} : *This is the official capacity. However, Standing Room Only (SRO) tickets are available that can increase this capacity by approximately 2,500+. : **6,000 seats were covered by a curtain; these and others made the stadium expandable to 55,883 during baseball playoffs and certain games in the last homestand and one-game playoff in October 2009. : ***Controlled by the [[Minnesota Vikings]] football team. Field dimensions are roughly comparable, with the left field area being a few feet closer to the plate, and the center field area being bounded by a 45° facet instead of a quarter-circle. The Twins' previous homes in the Twin Cities, [[Metropolitan Stadium]] and the Metrodome, were friendly to hitters. The team intended to build Target Field as a "neutral" park, favoring neither hitters nor pitchers. However, following the 2010 regular season, statistics showed that the park definitely played more to the favor of pitchers than hitters.{{clarify|date=July 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/05/sports/baseball/05twins.html?src=un&feedurl=http%3A%2F%2Fjson8.nytimes.com%2Fpages%2Fsports%2Fbaseball%2Findex.jsonp|title=Power Still Off at Twins’ New Home|last=Borzi|first=Pat|date=October 5, 2010|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=October 5, 2010}} It has since become well known as a "pitcher's park" in that it is difficult for batters to hit home runs and the pitcher has an advantage. Twins star [[Justin Morneau]] spoke for many of the players' concerns by calling "right-center to left-center... ridiculous" and that it is "almost impossible for a right-handed hitter to [homer to the] opposite field and very difficult for lefties".{{cite web |title=Justin Morneau Laments Target Fences|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=5796135|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=November 12, 2010|accessdate=November 12, 2010}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Portal|Baseball|Minnesota}} * [http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/min/ballpark/ Stadium site on twinsbaseball.com] * [http://www.ballparkauthority.com Minnesota Ballpark Authority] official website * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051029220113/http://www.house.leg.state.mn.us/bills/billnum.asp?billnumber=HF2480&session_number=0&ls_year=84&year=2005 The Twins Stadium Bill] MN State Legislature HF2480, SF2297 * [http://www.leg.state.mn.us/lrl/issues/baseball.asp Minnesota Legislative Reference Library: Baseball Stadiums] * [http://www.ballparkmagic.com BallparkMagic (Target Field Construction Blog)] * [http://www.mlb.com/min/ballpark/new_banter.jsp?content=qa Ballpark FAQ] * [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=5796135 sports.espn.go.com] * [http://wheresmyseat.net/target-field-minneapolis-mn/ Target Field Seating Chart] {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Minnesota Twins]] | years = 2010 – present | before = [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]] | after = Current }} {{succession box |title=Host of the [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game]] |years=[[2014 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|2014]] |before=[[Citi Field]] |after=[[Great American Ball Park]] }} {{s-end}} {{Minnesota Twins}} {{MLB Ballparks}} {{Big Ten Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Minneapolis skyscrapers}} {{Music venues of Minnesota}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Minnesota]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design basic silver certified buildings]] [[Category:Minnesota Golden Gophers baseball]] [[Category:Minnesota Twins stadiums]] [[Category:Major League Baseball venues]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]] [[Category:Sports venues in Minneapolis]] [[Category:Target Corporation]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Minnesota]]

'''Turun Toverit''' ('''TuTo''') is a sports club based in [[Turku]], [[Finland]]. It was established in 1929. Today it is best known of its [[ice hockey]] section [[TuTo Hockey]]. Other sections include sports like [[Association football|football]], [[basketball]], [[volleyball]], [[wrestling]] and [[athletics (sport)|athletics]]. TuTo is a member of [[Finnish Workers' Sports Federation]].
Most famous TuTo-athlete of all-time is [[Voitto Hellstén]], the [[Athletics at the 1956 Summer Olympics – Men's 400 metres|400 metres]] bronze medalist at the [[1956 Summer Olympics]].
== Ice hockey == {{main|TuTo Hockey}} TuTo Hockey plays currently in the Finnish second level [[Mestis]].
== Football == [[Association football|Football]] section of TuTo has played five seasons in the Finnish top division [[Mestaruussarja]].<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesf/finall.html Finland – Divisional Movements 1930–2013] Retrieved 30 June, 2013.</ref> Their best achievement is second place in 1947. Season 2014 TuTo plays in the fourth tier [[Kolmonen]].
== References == <references/>
== External links == *[http://www.tuto.fi/ TuTo Official Home Page] (in Finnish)
{{Finland-sport-stub}}

page.title: Venezuela at the 2007 Pan American Games

revision.text:
{{Infobox country at games | NOC = VEN | NOCname = [[Venezuelan Olympic Committee]] | year = 2007 | date = 13–29 July 2007 | games = Pan American Games | location = [[2007 Pan American Games|Rio de Janeiro]] | competitors = 382 | sports = | flagbearer = [[Silvio Fernández (fencer born 1979)|Silvio Fernández]] | officials = | gold = 12 | silver = 23 | bronze = 35 | rank = 7 | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | seealso = | website = [http://www.covoficial.com.ve/ www.covoficial.com.ve] }} The '''[[2007 Pan American Games|15th Pan American Games]]''' were held in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]], between 13 July 2007 and 29 July 2007.
==Medals==
===[[Image:Gold medal america.svg|20px]] Gold=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Cycling pictogram.svg|event=Cycling}} *Men's Points Race: [[Andris Hernández]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Fencing pictogram.svg|event=Fencing}} *Men's Épée Individual: [[Rubén Limardo]] *Women's Foil Individual: [[Mariana González (fencer)|Mariana González]] *Women's Foil Team: [[Jhohanna Fuenmayor]], [[Mariana González (fencer)|Mariana González]], [[María Martínez (fencer)|María Martínez]] and [[Yulitza Suárez]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Gymnastics (artistic) pictogram.svg|event=Gymnastics}} *Men's Individual All-Around: [[José Luis Fuentes]] *Women's Rings: [[Regulo Carmona]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Karate pictogram.svg|event=Karate}} *Men's Kumite (– 65 kg): [[Luis Plumacher]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Sailing pictogram.svg|event=Sailing}} *Men's Sunfish Class: [[Eduardo Cordeiro]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Swimming pictogram.svg|event=Swimming}} *Women's 50m Freestyle: [[Arlene Semeco]] *Women's 100m Freestyle: [[Arlene Semeco]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Tennis pictogram.svg|event=Tennis}} *Women's Singles: [[Milagros Sequera]]
===[[Image:Silver medal america.svg|20px]] Silver=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Boxing pictogram.svg|event=Boxing}} *Men's Light-Flyweight (– 48 kg): [[Kevin Betancourt]] *Men's Heavyweight (– 91 kg): [[José Payares]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Cycling pictogram.svg|event=Cycling}} *Men's Team Sprint: [[Hersony Canelón]], [[Andris Hernández]], and [[César Marcano]] *Men's Individual Sprint: [[Tomás Gil]] *Men's BMX: [[Jonathan Suárez]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Gymnastics (artistic) pictogram.svg|event=Gymnastics}} *Men's Pommel Horse: [[José Luis Fuentes]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Karate pictogram.svg|event=Karate}} *Men's Kumite (– 70 kg): [[Jean Carlos Peña]] *Men's Kumite (+ 80 kg): [[Mario Toro]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Swimming pictogram.svg|event=Swimming}} *Men's 1500m Freestyle: [[Ricardo Monasterio]]
===[[Image:Bronze medal (Americas).svg|20px]] Bronze=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Cycling pictogram.svg|event=Cycling}} *Women's Individual Road Race: [[Danielys García]] *Men's Team Pursuit: [[Tomás Gil]], [[Richard Ochoa]], [[Jaime Rivas]], and [[Franklin Chacón]] *Men's Madison: [[Richard Ochoa]] and [[Andris Hernández]] *Men's BMX: [[José Primera]] *Women's BMX: [[Kimmy Diquez]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Karate pictogram.svg|event=Karate}} *Women's Kumite (+ 60 kg): [[Yoly Guillen]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Swimming pictogram.svg|event=Swimming}} *Men's 100m Butterfly: [[Albert Subirats]] *Men's 4 × 100 m Freestyle: [[Albert Subirats]], [[Octavio Alesi]], [[Luis Rojas (swimmer)|Luis Rojas]], and [[Crox Acuña]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Taekwondo pictogram.svg|event=Taekwondo}} *Men's – 68 kg: [[Danny Miranda (taekwondo)|Danny Miranda]]
==Results by event==
===[[Triathlon at the 2007 Pan American Games|Triathlon]]===
